questions.text: Pertussis toxin acts by which of the following mechanism?
questions.solution:
Pertussis toxin acts by ADP-Ribosylation. It is expressed on the surface of Bordatella pertussis and is secreted into the environment.

Bordatella pertussis is a gram negative capsulated coccobacilli which causes whooping cough/pertussis (pertussis meaning intense cough)

Detection of bacilli in the upper respiratory tract by microscopy or culture confirms diagnosis. Respiratory samples can be collected by per-nasal swab, post-nasal swab or using the cough plate method. 

The Bordet-Gengou medium is used to culture the bacilli which are seen as small, dome-shaped, greyish white, refractile and glistening colonies, resembling 'bisected pearls' or 'mercury drops'. Confluent growth presents an 'aluminium paint' appearance.

 

 

Bordetella pertussis produces 3 hemagglutinins:

  • Pertussis toxin (PT)
  • FHA (Filamentous hemagglutinin)
  • Lipid factor

PT plays a major role in the pathogenesis of whooping cough. It acts by promoting lymphocytosis, increasing sensitization to histamine, and enhanced insulin secretion by means of ADP ribosylation that disrupts function of signal transduction in many cell types. FHA is responsible for facilitating the adhesion of Bordetella pertussis to the respiratory epithelium. FHA and PT also promote secondary infection by coating other bacteria such as Haemophilus influenzae and Pneumococci and assisting their binding to respiratory epithelium. This phenomenon has been termed 'piracy of adhesins'

Whooping cough is treated with erythromycin or one of the newer macrolides such azithromycin.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented with complaints of dysphagia and chest pain. A barium swallow study was done and the findings are given below. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The barium swallow image shows a bird beak appearance which is characteristic of achalasia cardia. Secondary achalasia is associated with Chagas disease which is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi infection and not Trypanosoma brucei.

Achalasia is characterized by the triad of incomplete lower esophageal sphincter relaxation, increased lower esophageal sphincter tone, and aperistalsis of the esophagus.

Primary achalasia is rare. It results from the degeneration of nitric oxide–producing neurons that normally induce lower esophageal sphincter relaxation.

Secondary achalasia is associated with the following conditions:

  • Chagas disease
  • Diabetic autonomic neuropathy
  • Infiltrative disorders such as malignancy, amyloidosis, and sarcoidosis
  • Systemic sclerosis
  • Lesions of dorsal motor nuclei (e.g., following polio)
  • Down syndrome
  • Allgrove (triple A) syndrome

Manometry is the gold standard test for diagnosis and it also distinguishes achalasia from other potential esophageal motility disorders.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus.

Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.

Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease

Clinical features:

  • dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • regurgitation
  • chest pain
  • weight loss
  • bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, Chagas’ disease, and pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation and Heller myotomy

questions.text: A male patient who presented with decreased vision is examined as shown in the image below. Which of the following value is measured by this procedure?
questions.solution:
The procedure performed in the given image is A-scan ultrasonography. It is used for determining the axial length of the eyeball and can be done by direct contact (as shown in the image) or by using a water bath over the eye (immersion ultrasonography).

The sound beam must be aligned with the visual axis for maximal precision. Each reflecting surface is represented by a spike on the oscilloscope monitor.

The power of an intraocular lens (IOL) is calculated by a biometer and the procedure is termed biometry.

The most common method of determining IOL power uses a regression formula called SRK (Sanders-Retzlaff-Kraff) formula, which is given below:

 P = A - 2.5L - 0.9K

Where,

  • P is the power of IOL.
  • A is a constant which is specific for each lens type.
  • L is the axial length of the eyeball in mm determined using the A-scan ultrasonography.
  • K is the average corneal curvature, which is determined by keratometry.

The image below shows A scan ultrasonography for determining the axial length of the eyeball.

questions.text: A blind folded person accurately identifies an object when placed in his hand. Which of the following is involved?
questions.solution:
The ability to identify or recognize an object in the absence of visual and auditory stimuli is known as stereognosis.

Stereognosis involves the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway, which carries information about fine touch, vibration, proprioception and contributes to stereognosis.

Anterior and lateral spinothalamic tracts carry pain and crude touch.

The Pyramidal tract and Rubrospinal tracts are descending pathways and are not sensory.

questions.text: What is the most common position of the subluxated lens in Marfan syndrome?
questions.solution:
The common position of the subluxated lens in Marfan syndrome is superior and temporal.

Ectopia lentis refers to a hereditary or acquired displacement of the lens from its normal position.

Causes:

Acquired

  • Trauma
  • Pseudoexfoliation
  • Inflammation, e.g. chronic cyclitis, syphilis
  • Hypermature cataract
  • Large eye, e.g. high myopia, buphthalmos
  • Anterior uveal tumours

Congenital:

  • Familial Ectopia lentis – Autosomal dominant, superotemporal displacement.
  • Ectopia lentis et pupillae - AR inheritance, displacement of the pupil and the lens in opposite directions
  • Marfan syndrome – Superotemporal displacement
  • Weil-Marchesani syndrome – Forward subluxation, spherophakia
  • Homocytinuria - Inferonasal displacement

Other systemic conditions associated with ectopia lentis include

  • Sulfite oxidase deficiency - Ectopia lentis is universal
  • Stickler syndrome - Retinal detachment is the most common ocular manifestation
  • Ehlers–Danlos syndrome
  • Hyperlysinaemia

questions.text: A patient is able to speak easily and fluently, but he is using incorrect words like 'den' for 'pen', associated with neologism and sentences which are incomprehensible. Which type of aphasia is likely in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The patient is most likely suffering from Wernicke's aphasia. The speech is easy and fluent but there are difficulties related to the output of language like  paraphasia (substitution of similar-sounding, non-words, or incorrect words) and neologisms (non-existent words).

It is a type of fluent aphasia which is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus due to the involvement of the Wernicke's area. The speech is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense.

Other options: 

Option B- Broca's or motor/non-fluent aphasia is seen in lesions of the inferior frontal gyrus which contains the motor speech area. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted, with a paucity of functional words.

Option C- Comprehension of written language and the ability to name objects are compromised in anomic aphasia. This aphasia is caused by damage to the angular gyrus that disrupts visual information processing and transmission to the Wernicke area.

Option D- Conduction aphasia is seen in lesions of the arcuate fasciculus, the bundle of nerve fibers connecting the Wernicke and Broca's areas. Repetition of words is impaired and paraphasias are observed, though not as much as in Wernicke aphasia.

questions.text: The bodies shown in the below image are seen in ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Lewy body. Lewy bodies may be found in the remaining neurons present in the substantia nigra in cases of Parkinson’s disease.

These are single or multiple, cytoplasmic, eosinophilic, round to elongated inclusions. They have a dense core, surrounded by a pale halo. On ultrastructural examination, Lewy bodies consist of fine filaments, composed of α-synuclein and other proteins, including neurofilaments and ubiquitin. The other major histologic finding is the presence of Lewy neurites that also contain aggregated α-synuclein.

The microscopic feature of Parkinson's disease is pallor of the substantia nigra and locus ceruleus. This occurs due to the loss of pigmented, catecholaminergic neurons in these regions associated with gliosis.

Other options

Option A- Pick's disease is a type of front temporal lobar degeneration. The surviving neurons show a characteristic swelling (Pick cells), and others contain Pick bodies, cytoplasmic, round to oval, filamentous inclusions that stain strongly with silver methods. 

The below image shows Pick bodies (marked with asterisks).

Option C- Microscopy of Huntington's disease shows loss of striatal neurons in the caudate nucleus, especially in the tail and in portions nearer the ventricle.

Option D- Important microscopic features of Alzheimer's disease are neuritic plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. Neuritic plaques are focal collections of dilated, tortuous axons and dendritic processes. They are present around an amyloid core. Neurofibrillary tangles are tau-containing bundles of filaments in the cytoplasm of the neurons. They can be elongated, flame-shaped, or may be rounded. (globose tangles)

The below image on the right top shows neuritic plaques and on the left bottom shows the presence of neurofibrillary tangles.

questions.text: A culture medium contains eggs and serum. Which method of sterilization should be used for this medium?
questions.solution:
Inspissation is used for sterilization of media containing eggs or serum. This method of sterilization involves heating at 80–85 °C for 30 minutes on 3 consecutive days.

Other Options:

Option A: Autoclaving: Heat at 121°C for 15 minutes at a pressure of 15psi (most commonly used).

Option C: Pasteurization: Milk is heated at either 63°C for 30 minutes (the holder method) or at 72°C for 15–20 seconds (the flash process), followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower. 

Option D: Tyndallization: This method is used for media containing sugars or gelatin. It involves steaming at 100°C for 20 minutes for 3 successive days. This method may not kill the spores of certain anaerobes and thermophiles.

questions.text: What is the ideal minimum duration of treatment (ATT) for tubercular meningitis?
questions.solution:
The ideal minimum duration of anti-tuberculosis therapy(ATT) for tubercular meningitis is 9 months.

X-pert MTB/RIF assay may be used as an adjunct in the diagnosis of TB meningitis. Steroids can also be used in HIV negative patients with TB meningitis.

The Index TB guidelines are for extrapulmonary TB.

Note: The Duration of ATT in lymph node and abdominal TB is 6 months.

questions.text: A 35-year-old soccer coach presents with pain in the left ear. He gives a history of trauma to the same ear a few days back and complains of pain and redness for the past week. On examination, his left ear feels warm, swollen, slightly tender to touch and is firm.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a red and stiff pinna. The clinical vignette along with the image is suggestive of perichondritis.

Aetiology:

  • MC cause is trauma either iatrogenic (surgical incision) or non iatrogenic (laceration, haematoma). It can be due to extension of infection from diffuse otitis externa or furuncle of meatus.
  • MC organism – Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Symptoms:

  • Initially, the pinna is red, hot, painful and stiff.
  • In the later stages, an abscess may form between the cartilage and perichondrium with necrosis of cartilage as the cartilage survives only on the blood supply from its perichondrium.

Treatment:

  • Treatment in the early stages consists of systemic antibiotics and the local application of 4% aluminium acetate compresses.
  • When an abscess has formed, it must be drained promptly and the culture and sensitivity of the pus obtained. The incision is made in the natural fold and devitalized cartilage is removed.
  • Some prefer to place a catheter in the abscess and administer a continuous drip of antibiotics, selected by culture and sensitivity for 7–10 days.

 

The above image shows cauliflower ear (Option -A) also known as perichondrial hematoma or wrestler's ear, is a deformity of the ear caused by trauma.

Treatment is the aspiration of the haematoma under strict aseptic precautions and a pressure dressing, carefully packing all concavities of the auricle to prevent reaccumulation. Aspiration may need to be repeated. When aspiration fails, incision and drainage should be done and pressure applied by dental rolls tied with through and through sutures. All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics.

 

The above image shows chondrodermatitis chronica helicis (Option-C) which is a small, nodular, tender, chronic inflammatory lesion occurring on the helix of the ear. Treatment is excision of the nodule with its skin and cartilage.

 

The above image shows otitis externa (Option-D) also called swimmer's ear. It is the inflammation of the ear canal. Treatment includes aural toilet, antibiotics, analgesics and medicated wicks.

questions.text: A young male patient comes for an eye assessment before a driver's license application. He states that he has difficulty interpreting the traffic lights. The ophthalmologist assesses him using the following method. Which of the following tests is being used?
questions.solution:
The patient's history is suggestive of color blindness, and the test being used is the Farnsworth–Munsell 100-hue test. 

This test is a spectroscopic test (the patient arranges color chips in ascending order) and consists of 85 caps of different hues in four racks. The color vision is judged according to the error score, such that a greater error score means poorer color vision. It is the most sensitive test for both congenital and acquired color vision defects.

Color blindness is the inability to appreciate one or more of the 3 primary colors, i.e. red, green, blue. It can be congenital or acquired. Hereditary conditions can be classified into dyschromatopsia (color confusion) and achromatopsia (rod monochromatism).  

Other options:

Option A: City university color vision is a spectroscopic test where a central colored plate should be matched with the closest hue from the four surrounding colors present in 10 plates.

Option B: Ishihara's pseudoisochromatic chart is a type of pseudoisochromatic chart in which there are patterns of colored and grey dots.  It will show one pattern to the normal individuals and another to a person with defective color vision. This is the most commonly used test for color vision.The below image shows an Ishihara's chart.

 

Option D: Holmgren's wools test is a color vision test where the patient is asked to make color matches from a selection of colored wools. The below image shows the test.

 

Other color vision tests include Edridge-Green lantern test (naming colors shown by a lantern) and Farnsworth D15 hue discrimination test (similar to Farnsworth–Munsell 100-hue test, but only uses 15 hues).

questions.text: A male patient presents with hearing loss and otorrhea for the last one week. He has a history of middle ear infections. The last episode resulted in the perforation of the tympanic membrane. His otoscopy findings are depicted below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and image above showing a perforated tympanic membrane and a large mass of white keratin debris suggest the likely diagnosis of secondary cholesteatoma. 

Cholesteatomas are keratinized squamous epithelium masses present in the middle ear cavity. They are described as skin in the wrong place. Although it is called cholesteatoma, this term is a misnomer as it is not composed of cholesterol crystals.

Cholesteatomas can be classified into the following types :

  • Primary acquired cholesteatomas occur in the absence of previous infection or perforation and patients present with hearing loss.
  • Secondary acquired cholesteatomas occur in those who have a preexisting perforation. 
  • Congenital cholesteatomas arise from the embryonic epidermal cells present in the middle ear cleft. It can be visualized as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane. 

Clinical features of cholesteatomas include hearing loss (due to perforation of tympanic membrane and middle ear bone destruction) and otorrhea. Cholesteatomas have a high potential to destroy the bone due to invasion and enzymatic bone destruction. 

Diagnosis of cholesteatoma can be done by history, examination, and radiography. CT can demonstrate bony defects such as ossicular erosion, mastoid aditus widening, and bony ear canal erosion.

Surgery is the only treatment for cholesteatoma. The procedure of choice is modified radical mastoidectomy (MRM), a type of canal wall-down tympanomastoidectomy.

Other options: 

Option A - Acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM) is more common in children. It would not have a pearly white mass on otoscopy. Clinical and otoscopy findings depend on the stage of ASOM. 

The following image shows mucopurulent discharge in the external auditory meatus seen in the stage of resolution of ASOM:

Option B - Glomus tumors are the most common benign tumors of the middle ear. The tumors comprise paraganglionic cells and arise from glomus bodies which resemble carotid bodies. Glomus bodies are present in the dome of the jugular bulb and on the promontory along the course of the tympanic branch of the IXth cranial nerve. A rising sun sign is seen on otoscopy when a tumor arises from the floor of the middle ear

questions.text: The synovial fluid analysis in a 45-year-old patient with pain and swelling over his ankle and metatarsophalangeal joints revealed the following finding as given below. Which of the following is true about the crystals shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows characteristic long, slender, needle-shaped urate crystals found in Gout. They are negatively birefringent under polarized light. 

Precipitation of monosodium urate crystals (MSU) is the hallmark of Gout. The lower temperature of the peripheral joints promotes their precipitation. MSU crystals are frequently found in the cytoplasm of the neutrophils and are arranged in small clusters in the synovium.

One of the factors leading to the precipitation of these crystals is Lead toxicity (not copper). The condition is then known as Saturnine Gout.

In contrast, Calcium pyrophosphate crystals are deposited in pseudo-gout (also known as Chondrocalcinosis). Calcium pyrophosphate crystals are rhomboid and positively birefringent.

questions.text: An elderly hypertensive patient is diagnosed with bilateral renal artery stenosis. He is also on treatment for diabetes mellitus. Which among the following drugs would be the most appropriate for the management of hypertension?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, Verapamil can be used for the management of hypertension in the patient. It does not have any adverse effect on glycemic control.

Option A- ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in bilateral artery stenosis. Normally angiotensin II reduces GFR by constricting afferent renal arteriole. However, when there is renal hypotension such as bilateral artery stenosis, it constricts the efferent arteriole thus increasing the GFR. If the RAAS system is blocked in a patient with bilateral renal artery stenosis, the GFR would get reduced significantly and may result in renal failure.

Options C and D- Beta-blockers and thiazides can worsen glycemic control and are not suitable in the given scenario.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with fissured tongue and cheilosis. Investigations showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. Among the following co-factors of enzyme complexes, which one is most affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from riboflavin/vitamin B2 deficiency. Both FAD and FMN require riboflavin for their synthesis.

Riboflavin (vitamin B2)

The active form of riboflavin is Flavin mononucleotide(FMN) and Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide (FAD). FMN is present in Complex I of ETC and FAD is present in Complex II in ETC.

FAD-dependent enzymes include succinate dehydrogenase, pyruvate dehydrogenase, alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, xanthine oxidase, and acyl CoA dehydrogenase

Riboflavin is synthesized in the body by intestinal flora. Dietary sources rich in riboflavin are liver, dried yeast, egg, and whole milk. Fish, whole cereals, legumes, and green leafy vegetables are also good sources of riboflavin. Riboflavin is light-sensitive. Hence riboflavin supplementation may be required during phototherapy for hyperbilirubinemia 

Clinical features of riboflavin deficiency include the proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries(the earliest sign of riboflavin deficiency) angular stomatitis, circumcorneal vascularization, cheilosis, magenta-colored tongue, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis. Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

Other options:

Options B and C: NAD and NADP are derived from niacin.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of fever and a pruritic rash over her body after swimming at a resort 3 days ago. Lesion culture reveals oxidase-positive, gram-negative bacillus. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever and a pruritic rash after swimming at a resort, with lesion culture revealing an oxidase-positive, gram-negative bacillus is suggestive of hot tub folliculitis caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Hot tub folliculitis presents as itchy maculopapular vesicles or pustules, typically appearing 1-4 days after bathing in contaminated hot tubs and pools. Associated symptoms may include fever, sore throat, headache, and malaise. Lesions are observed on the trunk, axillae, breasts, buttocks, and proximal extremities.

P. aeruginosa is an obligate aerobe, gram-negative, catalase-positive, and oxidase-positive bacteria that shows swarming motility. It produces a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. 

Diagnosis is helped by the fact that Pseudomonas grows well on most media with pigment production making its identification easy. It grows well on ordinary media, forms non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey medium, and is hemolytic on blood agar.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are false with respect to the inverse stretch reflex?
questions.solution:
Option D is a false statement as the inverse stretch reflex can be stimulated by a passive stretch as well as an active contraction.

When the tension in the muscle increases and surpasses a limit, contraction suddenly ceases and the muscle relaxes. This relaxation in response to an overt stretch is called the inverse stretch reflex.

The receptor involved in this reflex is the Golgi tendon organ (Option B). The Golgi tendon organ consists of a net-like collection of nerve endings that are arranged in series (Option C) within the muscle fibers. This arrangement allows for Golgi tendon organs to be stimulated by both active contraction and passive stretch of the muscle, unlike muscle spindles. One Golgi tendon organ innervates 3-25 muscle fibers. 

The afferents from the Golgi tendon organ are the Ib myelinated nerve fibers. The Ib nerve fibers synapse with inhibitory interneurons present in the spinal cord, which in turn synapse with the motor neurons supplying the muscles. Thus, this is a disynaptic reflex (Option A).

questions.text: In a patient with an acute exacerbation of asthma with severely compromised lung function who is not responsive to nebulized beta 2 agonists, which of the following is the steroid of choice for systemic use?
questions.solution:
Hydrocortisone is the steroid of choice in acute exacerbation of asthma (especially when the lung function is <30% predicted and there is no improvement with nebulized β2 agonist). It has the most rapid onset (5–6 hours after administration), compared to 8 hours with prednisolone.

It is given at a dose of 4 mg/kg initially, followed by a maintenance dose of 3 mg/kg every 6 hours. Intravenous therapy is usually given until a satisfactory response is obtained, and then it is replaced with oral prednisolone.

Mechanism of action of Corticosteroids in an acute asthma attack:

  • Increases responsiveness to Beta-2 agonists
  • Decreases mucous secretion
  • Decreases inflammatory cell response.

Steroids increase the transcription of beta 2 receptor genes and hence increases responsiveness to beta-2 agonists. Beta-2 agonists, on the other hand, increase the effect of steroids by enhancing the action of glucocorticoid receptors.

Theophylline increases the effects of steroids by activating enzyme histone deacetylase which is the target for steroids as well.

questions.text: A patient presented with corneal opacities and renal failure. On investigation, the enzyme lecithin cholesterol acyltransferase was found to be completely deficient. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the investigation showing complete deficiency of the enzyme lecithin cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT) points to the diagnosis of Norum's disease.

Familial lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase deficiency (FLD), also called Norum disease occurs when the deficiency of LCAT is complete. It is a rare genetic disorder inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. Here, the reverse cholesterol transport is affected leading to decreased circulating HDL cholesterol. Clinical features are dense corneal opacity and renal failure.

Fish-eye disease (FED) is due to a partial deficiency in LCAT activity.

Other options:

Option B: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Enlarged yellow-orange tonsils are pathognomonic. Low HDL levels are seen. Clinical features of Tangier disease include hyperplastic yellow-orange tonsils, hepatosplenomegaly, and peripheral neuropathy, which may be either relapsing-remitting or chronic progressive in nature

Option C: Abetalipoproteinemia is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a defect in the MTTP gene causing defective microsomal triglyceride protein. Here, loading apolipoprotein B with lipids is defective. Hence, few very low-density-lipoproteins (VLDLs) or chylomicrons are formed, leading to the accumulation of triacylglycerols in the liver and intestine.

Option D: Acid lipase enzyme deficiency can lead to Wolman's disease which is a lysosomal storage disease. The pathognomic feature of this condition is adrenal calcification. Infants generally present with failure to thrive, abdominal distention, vomiting, steatorrhea, and hepatosplenomegaly.

questions.text: A middle-aged man who presented with malaise, fever, a cutaneous ulcer, and preauricular lymphadenopathy was diagnosed with tularemia. Which among the following is a vector that transmits the disease?
questions.solution:
The vector that transmits tularemia is a hard tick.

Hard ticks are ectoparasites of vertebrate animals. They mainly transmit tularemia, tick typhus, and Kyasanur forest disease.

The dorsal surface of a hard tick is covered by scutum which is made up of chitin. This is absent in soft ticks. The head of the hard tick is at the anterior end. 

Diseases transmitted by hard ticks are:

  • Tick typhus (Rocky Mountain spotted fever)
  • Viral encephalitis (Russian spring-summer encephalitis)
  • Viral fevers (e.g. Colorado tick fever)
  • Viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g. Kyasanur Forest disease in India)
  • Tularemia
  • Tick paralysis
  • Human babesiosis

Tularemia is a tick-borne disease caused by Francisella tularensis. It is a gram-negative bacillus and a category A bioterrorism agent. It is a disease of rabbits and rodents. The most common mode of transmission is by direct contact with rodents or tick bites. They manifest as flu-like symptoms with cutaneous ulceration and preauricular lymphadenitis.

Other options:

Option A- Soft tick mainly transmits Q fever and relapsing fever.

Option C- Blackfly mainly transmits onchocerciasis.

Option D- Sandfly mainly transmits kala-azar and oriental sore.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of hypopigmentation of the skin. On examination, there was hypopigmentation of the iris. Investigations reveal neutropenia. A peripheral smear was done and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows giant inclusions in polymorphonuclear neutrophils, which along with oculocutaneous albinism, and neutropenia is suggestive of Chediak-Higashi syndrome. 

It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to loss-of-function mutation of the LYST gene encoding a protein known as lysosomal trafficking regulator. There is a defective fusion of phagosomes and lysosomes, resulting in defective phagocyte function and susceptibility to infections.

Clinical features occur due to defective transport of cell products. These include:

  • Significant pyogenic infections
  • Albinism (due to abnormalities of melanocytes)
  • Neurological abnormalities
    • Progressive intellectual decline
    • Cranial nerve palsies
    • Decreased deep tendon reflexes
    • Tremor
    • Abnormal gait (nerve cell dysfunction),
  • Bleeding (due to platelet dysfunction).

Peroxidase‐positive giant inclusions are seen in leukocytes. The only curative treatment available for Chédiak–Higashi syndrome is bone marrow transplantation.

Other options

Option A: Leukocyte adhesion deficiency results in the failure of leukocyte adhesion to endothelium, preventing the cells from migrating into tissues. This results in recurrent bacterial infections.

Option B: Chronic granulomatous disease is due to a defect in phagocytes oxidase which is required for the generation of superoxide. Its defect results in recurrent infections with catalase-positive microbes.

Option C: Wiskott Aldrich syndrome is characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and a marked vulnerability to recurrent infection, resulting in early death.

questions.text:
A patient presented with features of orange tonsils as shown in the image. His lipid profile showed almost nil HDL levels. Which of the following is deficient in this condition?

HDL - High density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with orange tonsils and nil HDL suggests a diagnosis of Tangier's disease. It is caused by a defect in ABCA1 receptors.

ABCA1 plays a role in the efflux of cholesterol from peripheral cells to HDL. Lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase (LCAT) converts cholesterol to cholesterol esters, which accumulate in the core of HDL. Thus defective ABCA1 will lead to almost nil HDL in the blood. 

Other options:

Option B: Defective LDL receptor points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia). This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and cholesterol are elevated. Such patients are at increased risk of developing atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency causes hyperchylomicronemia (type I hyperlipoproteinemia) due to defects in LPL or apo C-II. Eruptive xanthomas are seen. Chylomicrons and VLDL are elevated. LDL and HDL are low. There is no risk of coronary disease. Instead, patients have an increased risk of acute pancreatitis. This is due to very high triglyceride levels. It can also cause a milky appearance of plasma.

Option D: Acid lipase deficiency can lead to Wolman's disease, which is a lysosomal storage disease. Pathognomic feature of this condition is adrenal calcification. So patients generally present with adrenal insufficiency and are neonates.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic man comes in with symptoms of increasing pain in his forehead, swollen right eyelids, photophobia, and vesicles around his right eye, as shown in the picture below.  What treatment is most appropriate for him?
questions.solution:
This patient's growing pain around his left eye, together with the formation of several vesicles or pustules, suggests herpes zoster ophthalmicus, which is treatable with oral acylovir. Steroids are generally avoided in patients with herpes zoster because of the risk of further immunosuppression unless there is progressive ptosis, third nerve palsy or optic neuritis.

Herpes zoster ophthalmicus describes the reactivation of the varciella zoster virsus in the area supplied by the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve and accounts for around 10% of cases of shingles. It can be adequately treated with the help of oral acyclovir at a dose of 800mg for a period of 7 to 10 days.

Features of herpes zoster ophtalmicus incude a vesicular rash around the eye which may or may not include the eye itself as well as hutchinson's sign which is rash developed on the side of the nose and indicates nasociliary involvement. Patients with with involvement of the nasociliary nerve have a stronger risk of developing herpes zoster ophthalmicus.

Guidelines to be kept in mind while treating patients with herpes zoster ophtalmicus include :

  • Treatment initiation within 4 days of onset of rash.
  • Intravenous antivirals may be tried in case of severe infection or if patient is immunocompromised.
  • Pain can be addressed with NSAIDs and if uncontrolled opioid analgesics may prove beneficial.
  • Systemic steroid can be tried in patients with progressive ptosis, occulomotor nerve palsy and optic neuritis as a means to retard secondary inflammation.

questions.text: A camp was organized to screen for hypertension and diabetes. What level of prevention does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Screening is an example of secondary prevention.

Early diagnosis (including screening) and treatment is the component of secondary prevention. Some examples of secondary prevention are as follows:

  • Papanicolaou (Pap) smear for early detection of cervical cancer
  • Mammography, for early detection of breast cancer
  • Colonoscopies, for early detection of colon cancer
  • Blood Pressure Screening

Secondary prevention measures focus on the sub-clinical stage and the early clinical stage, such as dysplasia in this case. These measures enable early detection and prompt effective intervention at an earlier stage of the disease.

Prevention can be done at 4 levels: primordial, primary, secondary, and tertiary.

Other options:

Option A: Primordial prevention prevents the emergence or development of risk factors in population groups or countries where they have not appeared yet through individual and mass education. For example lifestyle modifications such as eating patterns and physical exercise to prevent obesity in later years.

Option C: Primary prevention includes intervention in the pre-pathogenesis stage of any disease through two strategies. 

  • Mass strategy: Health promotion in the entire population such as sanitation, and infection control.
  • High-risk strategy: Specific protection is given to high-risk groups through means such as immunization, and chemoprophylaxis.

Option D: Tertiary prevention is intervention in the late pathogenesis stage of a disease that has progressed beyond the early stages. It aims to limit impairment, disability and suffering.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is performed to rule out malingering for deafness?
questions.solution:
Stenger’s test is done to rule out malingering.

Stenger’s test is based on the principle that when sounds of two different intensities are delivered to both ears simultaneously, only the more intense sound is heard.

The patient should ideally be blindfolded. Two tuning forks of equal frequency are struck and placed 25 cm from each ear. The patient might claim to hear it only in the normal ear. Now the tuning fork is brought closer to the supposedly affected ear (within 8 cm) while retaining the position of the tuning fork on the side of the normal ear. The patient who is malingering would claim that he is unable to hear anything even though the tuning fork on the normal side would be in the same position where he claimed to have heard it earlier.

Other options:

Option A: Gelle’s is a tuning fork test done to clinically confirm otosclerosis.

Option C: Schwabach is a tuning fork test that compares the bone conduction of the patient with that of the examiner.

Option D: Rinne’s is a tuning fork test that compares bone conduction with air conduction.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man was admitted with a large wound on his leg for the past 3 months. Cultures from the wound margin revealed an MRSA infection. He was given linezolid. What is the mechanism of action of the above drug?

MRSA- Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus

choices.text: Binds to 30s subunit and inhibits protein synthesis
Binds to 50s subunit and inhibits protein synthesis
Disrupts the structure of cell membrane

questions.solution:
The drug linezolid binds to the P site of the 50s ribosomal subunit and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. It is an oxazolidinone that is active against various gram-positive organisms including methicillin-resistant staphylococci, and vancomycin-resistant staphylococci. 

Staphylococci become resistant by acquiring penicillin-binding protein (PBP) to become methicillin-resistant staphylococci. 

Linezolid and tedizolid are FDA-approved for the treatment of skin and soft tissue infections caused by streptococci and staphylococcus aureus (MSSA and MRSA). Linezolid is also approved for the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia due to S. pneumoniae and nosocomial pneumonia due to S. aureus.

Adverse effects include:

  • Myelosuppression (anemia, leukopenia, pancytopenia)
  • Thrombocytopenia (most common side effect)
  • Serotonin syndrome if given along with serotonergic drugs due to monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibition
  • Peripheral neuropathy, optic neuropathy, lactic acidosis

Other options:

Option A - Aminoglycoside antibiotics act by binding to the 30s ribosome and interfere with the initiation of protein synthesis. These bactericidal agents are mainly used to treat gram-negative bacterial infections. Ototoxicity, nephrotoxicity, and neuromuscular blockade are the most important adverse effects.

 Option C- Polymyxins act by interacting with the phospholipids and disrupting the structure of the cell membrane. It can be used systemically for bacteremia, pneumonia, bone/joint infections, burns, cellulitis, cystic fibrosis, endocarditis, gynecologic infections, meningitis, and ventriculitis. Polymyxin B is used topically for corneal ulcers, and eye and skin infections. Side effects include dose-related nephrotoxicity, muscle weakness, vertigo, and slurring of speech.

Option D - Glycopeptides inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding with D-alanyl-D-alanine and the class originator drug is vancomycin. It is used in the treatment of MRSA, clostridium difficile, meningitis, and staphylococcal endocarditis. Redman syndrome (erythema, flushing, tachycardia, and hypotension), ototoxicity, and nephrotoxicity are the most important adverse effects.

questions.text: A 37 year old male patient presented with painful genital ulcers for the past two weeks.Gram staining revealed gram-negative coccobacilli as shown in the image below.Which of the following would be a suitable culture medium for the suspected organism?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette along with the gram staining is  suggestive of chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Among the given options, chocolate agar with IsoVitaleX is the most suitable culture media for isolating the organism. 

H. ducreyi are gram-negative bacilli. On staining, they are sometimes seen arranged in a characteristic 'school of fish' or 'railroad track' appearance. 

Clinically, patients develop an H. ducreyi infection from sexual contact with an infected person. Following this, they develop a papule that progresses to a pustule and finally a circumscribed ulcer. This is called chancroid or 'soft sore' and it may be single or multiple, very painful, bleeds easily, and is non-indurated. The infection then spreads to the lymph nodes which become tender, inflamed, and then suppurated. 

Diagnosis is established by isolating the organism on culture. The specimen may include scrapings from the ulcer base and aspirate from the suppurated lymph node. Culture is difficult but they can be grown on chocolate agar enriched with IsoVitaleX and vancomycin, fresh clotted rabbit blood, or on the chorioallantoic membrane of the chick embryo. H. ducreyi requires media enriched with the X factor, but not the V factor for growth. 

Treatment is with a single oral dose of 1g of azithromycin. Other options include oral ciprofloxacin, IM ceftriaxone, and oral erythromycin. Sexual contacts of these patients must be treated regardless of whether they are symptomatic or not. 

Other options-

Option A - Thayer Martin medium is used for the isolation of Neisseria species. Neisseria meningitidis causes meningitis and meningococcemia presenting as acute fever with chills, malaise, and prostration. Neisseria gonorrhea causes urethritis, proctitis, vulvovaginitis, conjunctivitis, and disseminated gonococcal infection. 

Option B - Tellurite blood agar is used for the isolation of Corynebacterium species. Corynebacterium diphtheria causes diphtheria with variable presentation. It can lead to asphyxia, circulatory failure, toxemia and local necrotic changes. 

Option D - Ashdown's medium is used for the isolation of Burkholderia pseudomallei species. This bacteria causes melioidosis. It may be acute presenting as acute septicemia and typhoid or pneumonia-like disease. In the chronic form, it presents with multiple caseous or suppurative foci.

questions.text: Vertical transmission of an infectious agent from parent to progeny in vectors is seen in _______
questions.solution:
Vertical transmission of an infectious agent from parent to progeny in vectors is called transovarial transmission. It is seen in Rickettsia rickettsii (in ticks).

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient presented with severe restlessness, palpitations, facial flushing, and sweating. The patient had an episode of dysentery 2 days prior and had been prescribed medication for that. The patient reports taking alcohol 2 hours after his medications. Which of the following drug does not cause similar effects?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient developing symptoms like restlessness and flushing after taking alcohol after medication is suggestive of a disulfiram-like reaction. Among the given drugs, ofloxacin is not associated with a disulfiram-like reaction.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl with freckles on her face and limbs as shown below is brought with unusually sensitivity to sunlight. Early changes of squamous cell carcinomas are also noted on her face. Which of the following processes is most like to be defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum. It is an example of defective DNA nucleotide excision repair. There is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

Diagnosis is mainly clinical and it can be confirmed definitively by cellular tests for defective DNA repair. 

Management includes sun avoidance and regular follow-up to assess and treat any skin cancers. There is no cure for xeroderma pigmentosum.

questions.text: A dietician advising a patient regarding diet plans considers the specific dynamic action (SDA) values for proteins, lipids, and carbohydrates. Identify the correct sequence of SDA values in these substrates.
questions.solution:
Among the given options, option C represents the correct sequence of specific dynamic values (SDA) of proteins > lipids > carbohydrates.

Specific dynamic allowance (previously called the thermic effect of food): This refers to the increased heat production or increased metabolic rate following the intake of food (diet-induced thermogenesis).

The values of SDA are

  • 30% for proteins: This means that out of every 100 grams of proteins consumed, the energy available for doing useful work is 30% less than the calculated value.
  • 15% for lipids, and 
  • 5% for carbohydrates.

Importance: It is a common experience that during hot weather following the consumption of a protein-rich meal, one feels hot and humid for a while. On the other hand, in cold weather, the same would provide a comfortable feeling.

questions.text: The following egg belongs to:
questions.solution:
The image shows a non-operculated, yellowish-brown egg with a lateral spine near the rounded posterior end is suggestive of Schistosoma mansoni.

Adult worms of S. mansoni live in the inferior mesenteric vein and their infective form is fork-tailed cercaria.

Following skin penetration by cercariae, a pruritic rash termed cercarial dermatitis or swimmers itch develops locally which is self-limiting.

After 4- 8 weeks of the cercarial invasion, high worm load, and egg antigen stimuli lead to the formation of immune complexes which result in serum sickness-like illness termed Katayama fever. They present with high-grade fever, rash, arthralgia, hepatosplenomegaly. lymphadenopathy and eosinophilia. 

When eggs get deposited in the small intestine, patients develop abdominal pain and blood dysentery for a long time called intestinal bilharziasis. The eggs deposited in the intestinal wall lead to microabscesses, granulomas, hyperplasia, and fibrosis. 

The drug of choice is praziquantel 40mg/kg single oral dose. Oxamniquine 15mg/kg single oral dose is also an effective dose. It distorts the tegument of the male worm and makes the worm more susceptible to the lethal action of the immune system.

Option C- In Schistosoma japonicum, the egg has no spine but shows a lateral small rudimentary knob.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone acts via this pathway?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the JAK-STAT signaling pathway, which is associated with tyrosine kinase receptors. Among the given hormones leptin acts via this pathway.

Hormones that use receptor tyrosine kinase/ JAK-STAT signaling include the following:

  • Growth hormone
  • Fibroblast growth factor
  • Hepatocyte growth factor
  • Insulin
  • Insulin-like growth factor-1
  • Leptin
  • Prolactin
  • Vascular endothelial growth factor

Leptin is a hormone that is secreted by fat cells. The physiological effects of leptin are regulating appetite and energy balance. The leptin receptor acts via tyrosine kinase of the Janus kinase (JAK) family, JAK2. Leptin binds to the extracellular part of the leptin receptor, which causes phosphorylation (P) and activation of the intracellular JAK2. This causes phosphorylation of signal transducer and activation of transcription (STAT) proteins, which results in the transcription of target genes and the synthesis of proteins.

Phosphorylation of JAK2 also results in the activation of other intracellular enzyme pathways such as mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPK) and phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K).

Other options:

Hormones such as adrenal (Aldosterone)and gonadal steroid hormones, thyroid hormones, retinoid hormones, and vitamin D, bind with protein receptors inside the cell rather than on the cell surface. These hormones are lipid soluble and they readily cross the cell membrane and interact with receptors in the cytoplasm or nucleus.

Vasopressin in the epithelial cells acts via V2 receptor. They use adenylyl cyclase as their second messenger system. Vasopressin in the vascular smooth muscles acts via V1 receptor that uses phospholipase C as the second messenger system.

questions.text: The HIV sentinel surveillance includes all of the following populations except ______________
questions.solution:
Sentinel surveillance of HIV is usually not done for STD clinic attendees.

Sentinel surveillance is used to augment the notification systems used in the surveillance of diseases.

Till 2012-13, STD sites were also included in the HIV sentinel surveillance but from 2014-15, these sites were entirely discontinued, since the STD data had significant biases.

The study population for HIV sentinel surveillance includes:

  • Female sex worker: Women who are engaged in consensual sex for money or payment in kind, as a means of livelihood in the last six months
  • Men who had anal or oral sex with a male partner in the last month.
  • Injection drug users: Men and women who use addictive substances or drugs for recreational or non-medical reasons, through injections, at least once in the last three months.
  • Transgender: Person whose identity does not conform unambiguously to conventional notions of male or female gender roles, but combines or moves between these.
  • Single male migrants: Single male, living at a place other than the place of usual residence without his spouse or family, for the purposes of work and visiting his home town at least once a year.
  • Long-distance truckers: Truckers who travel more than 800 km one way between source and destination.
  • A pregnant woman of age 15-49 years and attending the antenatal clinic for the first time.

questions.text: A newborn baby is vaccinated against tuberculosis disease. All of the following are true about the vaccine except:

choices.text: The dose given at birth is 0.05 ml
Distilled water is preferred for reconstitution

questions.solution:
BCG vaccine is primarily used against tuberculosis disease. Normal saline is recommended for reconstituting the vaccine, as distilled water may cause irritation. Hence, option D is not true. 

BCG (bacillus of Calmette and Guerin) is the only live bacterial vaccine. The WHO has recommended the Danish 1331 strain for the production of the BCG vaccine. It protects against severe forms of childhood tuberculosis and tuberculous meningitis. It also reduces morbidity and mortality against primary tuberculosis.

There are two types of BCG vaccine: the liquid (fresh) vaccine and the freeze-dried vaccine. The freeze-dried vaccine is a more stable preparation (option B) than the liquid vaccine. Currently, the vaccine is distributed in the freeze-dried form because of better storage qualities. Normal saline is recommended for reconstituting the vaccine, as distilled water may cause irritation. The reconstituted vaccine may be used up within 3 hours.

The usual strength for vaccination is 0.1 mg in 0.1 ml volume. The dose given at birth (option A) and for newborns < 4 weeks of age is 0.05 ml. It is injected intradermally (option C) just above the insertion of the left deltoid muscle using a tuberculin syringe.  

A papule develops at the vaccination site after 2-3 weeks. It increases slowly in size and then subsides or breaks into a shallow ulcer after 5 weeks. Healing occurs spontaneously within 6 to 12 weeks, leaving a permanent, tiny, round scar, typically 4-8 mm in diameter. Usually, the individual becomes Mantoux-positive after 8-14 weeks. 

Complications include prolonged severe ulceration at the vaccination site, suppurative lymphadenitis, osteomyelitis, and disseminated infection. It should not be given to patients with generalized eczema, infective dermatosis, hypogammaglobulinemia, immunodeficiency state, or pregnancy.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with chronic tonsillitis presented to the OPD with complaints of a gritty sensation in her throat. On palpation and probing, you confirm the sensation. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the clinical scenario, the patient having chronic tonsillitis with a gritty sensation in the throat suggests a possible diagnosis of tonsilloliths. 

Tonsilloliths are complications of chronic tonsillitis and are mostly seen in adults. They are calcium and magnesium-rich calculi of the tonsils that occur due to the blocking of crypts and retention of debris. They give rise to a gritty sensation in the throat and can be confirmed with palpation or probing. They may enlarge and ulcerate through the tonsil. Tonsilloliths are treated by removal of stone or tonsillectomy.

Other options: 

Option A: Intratonsillar abscess is a complication of acute tonsillitis where pus is accumulated in the tonsils. It presents with inflamed, tender tonsils with significant pain and dysphagia. They can be treated with antibiotics, drainage, or tonsillectomy at a later date. 

Option C: Tonsillar cyst is an asymptomatic yellowish swelling over the tonsil due to blockage of a tonsillar crypt. It is treated by incision and drainage.

Option D: Lingual tonsil abscess is a severe complication of acute tonsillitis as it can cause laryngeal edema. Jugulodigastric nodes are commonly involved. Dysphagia, excessive salivation and painful tongue protrusion are some of the clinical findings seen in this condition.

questions.text: Gastric emptying is mainly regulated by______
questions.solution:
Gastric emptying is mainly regulated by enteric reflexes.

Regulation of gastric emptying is mainly by the inhibitory feedback signals from the duodenum that includes enterogastric reflex and hormonal feedback by cholecystokinin.

Enterogastric reflex:

When food enters the duodenum, multiple nervous reflexes are initiated from the duodenal wall. They strongly inhibit the pyloric pump propulsive contractions and increase the tone of the pyloric sphincter.

These reflexes are mediated by three routes:

  • Directly from the duodenum to the stomach through the enteric nervous system in the gut wall (major role).
  • Through inhibitory sympathetic nerve fibers to the stomach (minor role).
  • Vagus nerves to the brain stem where they inhibit the normal excitatory signals transmitted to the stomach (minor role).

Hormonal feedback:

Cholecystokinin is released from the mucosa of the jejunum in response to fatty substances in the chyme. This hormone acts as an inhibitor to block increased stomach motility caused by gastrin.

Vagus nerve innervates parietal cells and stimulates H+ secretion directly.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is Ach, the receptor on the parietal cells is muscarinic (M3)

The second messengers for CCK are IP3 and increased intracellular [Ca2+].

Atropine, a cholinergic muscarinic antagonist, inhibits H+ secretion by blocking the direct pathway, which uses ACh as a neurotransmitter. However, it does not block H+ secretion completely because it does not inhibit the indirect pathway, which uses GRP as a neurotransmitter

Vagus nerve innervates G cells and stimulates gastrin secretion, which then stimulates H+ secretion.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is GRP (not ACh).

Vagotomy eliminates both direct and indirect pathways.

Gastrin

Released in response to eating a meal (small peptides, distension of the stomach, vagal stimulation).

Stimulates H+ secretion by interacting with the cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptor on the parietal cells.

The second messenger for gastrin on the parietal cell is IP3/Ca2+.

  

Histamine

Released from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in the gastric mucosa and diffuses to the nearby parietal cells.

Stimulates H+ secretion by activating H2 receptors on the parietal cell membrane.

The H2 receptor is coupled to adenylyl cyclase via a Gs protein.

The second messenger for histamine is cAMP.

H2 receptor–blocking drugs, such as cimetidine, inhibit H+ secretion by blocking the stimulatory effect of histamine.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a unilateral throbbing headache associated with nausea and vomiting. She has had similar episodes in the past where the headache usually lasts for 1-2 days, and she prefers sitting in a dark room during the attacks. She also gives a history of a myocardial infarction 2 years ago. Which of the following drugs cannot be prescribed to this patient to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of an acute attack of migraine. Sumatriptan is contraindicated in a patient with a history of myocardial infarction.

Triptans are selective 5HT 1B/1D agonists. They are indicated in the management of acute attacks of migraine. They act by arresting the nociceptive nerve signalling in the trigeminovascular system. They also act by vasoconstricting, not only the intracranial vessels but other vessels too. Hence it is contraindicated in patients with a history of ischemic or vasospastic coronary artery disease (history of stroke or transient ischemic attacks), cerebrovascular or peripheral vascular disease, hemiplegic or basilar migraines, or ischemic bowel diseases. Triptans are also contraindicated in patients with uncontrolled hypertension.

Migraine is the second most common cause of headaches and is seen more commonly in women. It presents as an episodic headache associated with nausea, vomiting, photosensitivity, and sensitivity to sound (phonophobia). Common triggers include bright lights, sounds, and hunger. The release of vasoactive peptides such as calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) by the trigeminal nucleus cells is the theory used to explain the pathogenesis of the condition. The neurotransmitters serotonin and dopamine also play a part.

A migraine attack has four phases: premonitory (prodrome), aura, headache, and postdrome; each has distinct and sometimes disabling symptoms, which may overlap.

Migraine can broadly be classified into:

  • Migraine without aura (70-80%): Common migraine.
  • Migraine with aura (20-30%): Classic migraine.

The migraine disability assessment score (MIDAS) can be used to assess the severity of the condition. Avoidance of recognized triggers is helpful to avoid symptoms. The various drugs used to treat an acute attack of migraine are non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), triptans, CGRP Receptor Antagonists (rimegepant), 5-HT1/F receptor agonists (lasmiditan), and dopamine receptor antagonists (domperidone). 

The various FDA-approved drugs used in prophylaxis include propranolol, valproate, topiramate, and flunarizine.

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination, no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At Least 2 of the following features

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at Least 1 of the following features

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with elevated blood pressure in the upper extremities and lower blood pressure in the lower extremities. Which arteries are directly responsible for the finding marked on his chest X-ray given below?
questions.solution:
This is a clinical vignette of coarctation of the aorta, characterized by elevated blood pressure in upper limbs, lower blood pressure in lower limbs, and notching of inferior margin of ribs on chest X-ray. Narrowing of the aorta leads to increased blood flow and enlargement of collateral posterior intercostal arteries, which cause rib notching. 

Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital narrowing occurring just proximal, opposite, or distal to the ligamentum arteriosum attachment. The key clinical indicator is reduced or absent pulses in the femoral arteries causing decreased lower extremity blood pressure. 

The body compensates through extensive collateral circulation, causing dilatation of internal thoracic (Option D), subclavian, and posterior intercostal arteries. Notching of lower rib borders, visible on radiographs, results from erosion by dilated intercostal arteries.

Other options: 

Option A and C: Subcostal arteries and internal mammary arteries are not the primary contributors to collateral circulation in this condition.

Option D: Although internal thoracic arteries are dilated due to collateral circulation, rib notching is caused by intercostal arteries.

questions.text: What is the position of the vocal cords in normal quiet respiration?
questions.solution:

Option B: Intermediate, or cadaveric position of vocal cords (3.5 mm from midline) is seen in paralysis of both RLN and superior laryngeal nerves. It is the neutral position of the cricoaretynoid joint.

Option D: Full abduction (9.5 mm from the midline) of vocal cords is seen normally during deep inspiration.

questions.text: The STEPS by WHO is aimed at:

choices.text: Surveillance of risk factors for non-communicable diseases
Surveillance of risk factors for communicable diseases
Surveillance of mortality due to nosocomial infections
Surveillance of morbidity in the visually impaired

questions.solution:
WHO STEPwise approach to Surveillance (STEPS) is used for surveillance of adult risk factors for non-communicable diseases and for stroke surveillance.

WHO STEPS approach is a survey methodology developed to assess risk factors of non-communicable diseases (NCD). It helps the countries to establish an NCD surveillance system. The steps include the following:

  • Questionnaires contain questions about behavioral risk factors like tobacco use, alcohol use, diet, and physical activity. 
  • Physical measurements contain blood pressure, height, weight, and waist size
  • Biochemical measurements contain blood glucose, blood lipids, urinary sodium, and creatinine.  

Surveillance is defined as systematic and continuous data analysis and taking appropriate preventive actions according to the results obtained. Identification of cases that are missed and not notified is known as sentinel surveillance. It is used in communicable diseases such as HIV, malaria, etc. The study population for HIV sentinel surveillance are sex workers, IV drug abusers, transgender people, migrant workers, truck drivers, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is inconsistent with nasopharyngeal carcinoma?

choices.text: Most common site of origin is the fossa of Rosenmuller
CN V involvement leads to reduced corneal reflex
Hearing loss is the most common presentation
Tumor can invade the orbit and cause exophthalmos

questions.solution:
The statement ‘hearing loss is the most common presentation’ is inconsistent with nasopharyngeal carcinoma. 

The most common presenting symptom is cervical lymphadenopathy, occurring in 60-90% of cases. 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the nasopharynx. The theories for etiology include genetics, infection with Epstein-Barr virus, air pollution, and smoking.

It has three types -

  1. Keratinizing carcinoma
  2. Nonkeratinizing differentiated carcinoma
  3. Nonkeratinizing undifferentiated carcinoma. 

The most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller (Option A). From here, it can spread extensively in any direction locally. It also can spread lymphatically to the cervical, retropharyngeal, or parapharyngeal lymph nodes. 

Trotter's triad consists of ipsilateral conductive hearing loss (eustachian tube blockage), trigeminal neuralgia of the mandibular division, and palatal asymmetry due to invasion of levator palatini muscles may be seen. This triad occurs in malignant tumors of the lateral nasopharyngeal wall due to extensive invasion. 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal - obstruction, discharge, rhinolalia clausa, epistaxis
  • Ear - eustachian tube obstruction leading to conductive hearing loss or recurrent otitis media. 
  • Ophthalmoneurologic - all the cranial nerves (CN) may be involved. 
    • CN VI - squint and diplopia, the most common cranial nerve involved
    • CN III, IV, VI, - ophthalmoplegia
    • CN V - reduced corneal reflex (Option B)
    • CN II - exophthalmos (Option D)
    • CN IX, X, XI - jugular foramen syndrome
    • Horner’s syndrome
  • Cervical lymph node metastasis
  • Distant metastasis to the bone, liver, and lung. 

Diagnosis is made by high resolution, contrast-enhanced CT of the neck.

The treatment of choice is radiotherapy. Stage I and II can be treated with radiotherapy alone, while higher stages require combination treatment with radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

  2. Medial medullary syndrome

questions.solution:
The given image shows the Circle of Willis and the marked vessels are:

  • A- Posterior cerebral artery
  • B- Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C- Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • D- Anterior spinal artery

The correct match is:

Syndromes Vessels involved

Posterior inferior cerebellar artery.
Medial medullary syndrome Anterior spinal artery
Weber's syndrome Posterior cerebral artery
Lateral inferior pontine syndrome  Anterior inferior cerebellar artery

 

Circle of Willis is a large arterial anastomosis that unites the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems. It lies in the subarachnoid space within the basal cisterns that surround the optic chiasma and infundibulum.

Lateral medullary syndrome/Wallenberg syndrome. This may result from a stroke affecting the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. 

The clinical findings correspond to the neuroanatomical structures affected in the lateral portion of the medulla:

  • Descending tract and nucleus of CN V (trigeminal)- loss of pain and sensation over the ipsilateral half of the face.
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle – ipsilateral ataxia (gait and limb)
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract – loss of pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body. 
  • IX and X CN - ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex giving rise to dysphagia, dysarthria.
  • Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
  • Descending sympathetic tract – ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis).

Medial medullary syndrome. It is due to the involvement of the anterior spinal artery. Patients present with:

  • Lower motor neuron lesion of CN XII- Ipsilateral tongue weakness with deviation toward the lesion.
  • Medial lemniscus- Loss of contralateral touch and proprioception.
  • Pyramidal tract- Contralateral hemiparesis.

Weber syndrome: It is due to the involvement of the posterior cerebral artery. It affects the cranial nerve (CN) III, ventral midbrain, and corticospinal tract. Patients will have contralateral hemiplegia and contralateral paralysis of the lower part of the face. Ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy where the eyeball is deviated laterally because of the paralysis of the medial rectus muscle, and drooping of the upper lid (ptosis). The pupil is dilated and fixed to light and accommodation.

The lateral inferior pontine syndrome is due to occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery. Ipsilaterally it presents as,
  • Seventh nerve- Vertigo, horizontal and vertical nystagmus, and facial paralysis.
  • Cochlear nucleus- Paralysis of conjugate gaze to the affecting side (preservation of convergence), deafness, tinnitus.
  • Nucleus of trigeminal nerve- Impaired sensation over the face.

Contralaterally it presents as:

  • Spinothalamic tract- Impaired pain, and thermal sensation over one-half the body.

questions.text: Which of the following stimuli is best perceived by Ruffini corpuscles?

choices.text: Point discrimination, precise location, tapping, and flutter

questions.solution:
Ruffini corpuscles detect stretch and joint rotation.

Ruffini corpuscles are capsulated, enlarged, dendritic endings. They are located in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin, and in joint capsules. They are slowly-adapting receptors. 

The image below shows a Ruffini corpuscle.

Meissner's corpuscles are present mainly in the dermis of non-hairy skin, particularly in the fingertips, lips, and other locations where tactile discrimination is well developed. They have small receptive fields which help in two­ point discrimination. Meissner's corpuscles are rapidly adapting receptors that sense point discrimination, precise location, tapping, and flutter. These are encapsulated nerve endings of a large myelinated sensory nerve (Aβ type).

The image shows the histology of Meissner's corpuscle in the dermis.

Pacinian corpuscles are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptors. They are present in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin. They are composed of a nerve ending which is encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue that give it an onion-like appearance. These receptors respond to fast vibration and deep pressure and adapt very rapidly. The sensory nerves from cutaneous mechanoreceptors are myelinated Aα and Aβ fibers.

The image shows the histology of the Pacinian corpuscle.

Merkel discs are seen in the epidermis of glabrous skin. They are slowly adapting receptors and have very small receptive fields. These receptors detect vertical indentations of the skin. They are expanded dendritic endings.

The image below shows a Merkel disc.

Pain and temperature sensations arise from receptors located on unmyelinated sensory neurons present throughout the glabrous skin, hairy skin, and deep tissue. Impulses from nociceptors are transmitted via thinly myelinated Aδ fibres and unmyelinated C fibres.

Activation of Aδ fibres is responsible for first pain (also called fast pain). It is a rapid response and helps in the discrimination of pain or the ability to localize the site and intensity of the noxious stimulus. It is mediated by the release of glutamate. An example is a pinprick.

Activation of C fibres is responsible for delayed second pain (also called slow pain). It is a dull, intense, diffuse, and unpleasant feeling associated with a noxious stimulus. Second pain is mediated by the release of a combination of glutamate and substance P. Example is visceral pain.

Types of nociceptors :

  • Mechanical nociceptors respond to strong pressure (eg, from a sharp object). 
  • Thermal nociceptors are activated by skin temperatures above 45°C or by severe cold (<20°C).
  • Chemically sensitive nociceptors respond to chemicals such as bradykinin, histamine, high acidity, and environmental irritants.
  • Polymodal nociceptors respond to combinations of these stimuli.
