questions.text: Which biochemical cycle/process is used by monoclonal antibodies in hybridoma technology?
questions.solution:
It is the Purine salvage pathway that is utilized by monoclonal antibodies in hybridoma technology.

Monoclonal antibodies refer to the antibodies produced by a group of lymphocytes that produce antibodies against a single antigen. These antibodies are produced by hybridoma technology. 

In this technology, the B-lymphocytes of mice spleen are immunized with an antigen to produce a specific antibody. These specific antibody-producing B lymphocytes are then fused with myeloma cells that can multiply indefinitely.

The myeloma cells are deficient in the hypoxanthine-guanine-phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) gene and do not produce immunoglobulins. Therefore, the resulting hybrid cell is producing antibodies against a single antigen indefinitely. These hybrid cells are cultured in a HAT medium (containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine) and the monoclonal antibodies are obtained. It is well-established that nucleotides present in DNA and RNA consist of purine and pyrimidine bases. The synthesis of these nucleotides can occur through either the De novo pathway or the salvage pathway. Consequently, the inclusion of aminopterin in the HAT medium effectively inhibits the De novo pathway, thereby rendering the synthesis of purine dependent on the salvage pathway. However, it should be noted that the Salvage pathway exclusively takes place in the presence of the enzymes HGPRT and thymidine kinase. The hybridoma cell is uniquely capable of proliferating on the HAT medium due to its distinct composition. Specifically, the myeloma component of the hybridoma possesses the capacity for repetitive cellular division, while the plasma cell component contains the enzyme HGPRT. Consequently, the hybridoma cells can sustain growth and viability over an extended period when cultivated on the HAT medium.

Hybridoma technology is a method for producing large numbers of identical antibodies (monoclonal antibodies).

Hybridomas are somatic cell hybrids produced by fusing the antibody-forming spleen cells with myeloma cells. The resultant hybrid thus has both the antibody-producing ability of the B-cell and the ability to multiply indefinitely of the myeloma. 

The following are the steps involved in hybridoma technology:

  • Mice are immunized with an antigen.
  • After several weeks of immunization, blood samples are obtained from mice for measurement of serum antibodies.
  • When the antibody titer is high enough, mice are commonly boosted by injecting antigen without adjuvant, intraperitoneally or intravenously.
  • Then the mice are euthanized and their spleens removed for in vitro hybridoma cell production.
  • Fusing antibody-producing spleen cells, which have a limited life span, with myeloma cells (derived from an immortal tumour of lymphocytes) results in a hybridoma that is capable of unlimited growth.
  • The cells are cultured in a medium containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine (HAT medium) which allows only the fused cells to survive in culture.
  • Monoclonal antibodies are then harvested.

Applications of hybridoma technology

  • Listing lymphocyte subpopulations
  • Specific cell quantitative preparation
  • As an immunosuppressant in therapeutic settings
  • Blood component nephelometric assays
  • ELISA testing
  • Quantitative purification of antigens.
  • Common therapeutic applications for monoclonal antibodies

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the procedure shown in the image?

choices.text: The concept of the procedure was introduced by Goldmann.
It is used to treat after cataract
It is based on the Imbert-Fick law
It is used to investigate glaucoma

questions.solution:
The instrument shown is an applanation tonometer, which is used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP). 

Tonometers are used to measure intraocular pressure. There are two types of tonometers. They are indentation and applanation tonometers. Increased intraocular pressure is seen in cases of glaucoma.

Applanation tonometry is more accurate. The concept behind the procedure was introduced by Goldmann. The applanation tonometer measures the amount of force needed to applanate (flatten) a known corneal area based on the Imbert-Fick law. Imbert-Fick law states that the pressure inside a sphere(P) is equal to the force (W) required to flatten its surface divided by the area of flattening (A).

P = W/A

Goldmann tonometer, tono-pen, Perkin's applanation tonometry, and pneumatic tonometer are all based on the principle of applanation tonometry. 

Indentation tonometry is based on the principle that a plunger will indent more on a soft eye than a hard eye. Schiotz tonometer is the most widely used tonometer as it is cheap and hand-held. However, it can give false readings if used in an eye with abnormal scleral rigidity.

*Note - After cataract, otherwise known as posterior capsular opacification, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. Treatment includes posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser.

questions.text:
Match the following microscopic findings to the disease conditions in which they are seen.
Microscopic findings Lung disease
1. Coal-laden macrophages  A. Silicosis
2. Golden-brown fusiform rods  B. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
3. Non-necrotizing granulomas  C. Anthracosis
4. Nodules of whorled collagen fibers D. Asbestosis
questions.solution:
The correct match is Option 2: 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A.

Anthracosis/ coal workers' pneumoconiosis is a pulmonary condition seen in coal miners. It is caused due to the phagocytosis of the inhaled carbonaceous pigment by the alveolar or interstitial macrophages and its subsequent accumulation in the connective tissue spaces. With continued exposure, lung tissue undergoes progressive massive fibrosis. The upper lobes and upper zones of the lower lobes of the lungs are commonly involved.

Microscopic features consist of coal-laden macrophages, black pigment, and dense collagenous interstitial fibrosis (in advanced stages), as shown in the image below.

 

Asbestosis occurs due to the inhalation of crystalline hydrated silicates (asbestos). It is characterized by diffuse parenchymal interstitial fibrosis. It usually begins in the lower lobes of the lungs. Other asbestos-related diseases include pleural plaques, recurrent pleural effusions, lung carcinoma, and mesothelioma.

Hallmark microscopic findings are golden brown, fusiform or beaded rods called asbestos bodies, as shown in the image below. These are formed when the asbestos fibers phagocytosed by the macrophages are coated by iron-containing proteinaceous material derived from phagocyte ferritin. Pleural plaques of dense collagen that may be calcified are the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure. They involve the anterior and posterolateral aspects of the parietal pleura and the diaphragmatic domes.

 

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is an immunologically mediated granulomatous disease that occurs in response to continuous exposure to inhaled organic antigens (mold, hay dust, bird proteins, thermophilic bacteria in air-conditioning units). Pathological changes in response to such exposures are mediated by the CD4+ and CD8+ T-lymphocytes (type IV hypersensitivity reactions) and proinflammatory chemokines.

Microscopic findings include interstitial pneumonitis (lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages) and non-necrotizing granulomas, as shown in the image below. Chronic disease gives rise to obliterative bronchiolitis and honeycombing.

 

Silicosis occurs due to inhalation of crystalline silicon dioxide (silica) as seen in individuals employed in concrete work and sandblasting. Macrophages incorporate inhaled silica particles, thereby activating and releasing inflammatory mediators (IL-1, IL-8) that cause fibroblast recruitment. Subsequently, collagen is deposited in the interstitium. Upper lung zones and hilar lymph nodes are commonly involved.

Microscopy reveals coalescent nodules of whorled collagen fibers surrounded by a peripheral zone of silica-laden macrophages, as shown in the image below. As the disease progresses, these nodules coalesce into scars. Sometimes, thin sheets of calcification can occur in hilar lymph nodes, giving an eggshell appearance.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient presented with a painless mass in the parotid region. Examination revealed a 5-cm rounded, well-demarcated tumor. Biopsy of the tumor revealed myoepithelial cells intermingled with myxoid, mucoid, and cartilaginous areas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and histopathological findings are suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma of the parotid gland.

Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms and the parotid gland is most commonly involved. They are benign tumors that consist of a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells. Therefore they are also termed mixed tumors.

Pathology:

Gross features:

  • The tumors are rounded, well-demarcated, measuring <6 cm.
  • They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate.
  • The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma.

On microscopy epithelial and mesenchymal components are visible. Epithelial components resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells that are arranged in the form of ducts, acini, irregular tubules, or sheets of cells. These components are dispersed in the mesenchymal components consisting of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing cartilage or bone.

The image below shows pleomorphic adenoma of the salivary gland consisting of mixed epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right).

Other options:

Option A: Warthin tumor is the second most common salivary gland neoplasm. Histologically, the tumor shows epithelial and lymphoid elements. The epithelium typically consists of a double layer of oncocytic epithelial cells. The inner layer contains columnar cells while the outer layer contains cuboidal cells.

Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary gland, commonly affecting the parotid gland. Histology shows mucinous, intermediate, and squamous elements, with small to large mucus-filled vacuoles.

Option D: Adenoid cystic carcinoma involves minor salivary glands, commonly the palatine glands. Histology shows tumor cells, organized in a cribriform growth pattern, resembling swiss cheese.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: Which of the following gives rise to major and minor calyces in the kidneys?
questions.solution:
The division of the ureteric bud gives rise to major and minor calyces in the kidney.

The kidney develops from 3 sources as follows:

  • Metanephric blastema (Option C) gives rise to the excretory system of the kidney. It forms the Bowman's capsule, the proximal convoluted tubule, the loop of Henle, and the distal convoluted tubule. 
  • The ureteric bud, an outgrowth of the mesonephric duct, gives rise to the kidney's collecting system. It forms the collecting ducts, minor and major calyces, renal pelvis, and ureter.
  • Angiogenic mesenchyme (Option A), which migrates into the metanephric blastema, gives rise to the glomeruli and the vasa recta. 

Option D: Primitive urogenital sinus arises from the ventral portion of the cloaca and gives rise to the vesicourethral canal cranially and definitive urogenital sinus caudally. The vesicourethral canal gives rise to the urinary bladder, female urethra, and prostatic part of the urethra in males. The definitive urogenital sinus gives rise to the membranous and penile urethra except for the terminal part in males.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of the condition associated with the following clinical finding?
questions.solution:
The image shows discrete raised white dots at the limbus of the cornea, called Horner Tranta's spots, typically seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC), which is a type of allergic conjunctivitis. 

Vernal keratoconjunctivitis, also known as spring catarrh or warm weather conjunctivitis is a recurrent inflammation of the conjunctiva with seasonal incidence, commonly occurring in individuals with an atopic background and seasonal allergies due to Th2 lymphocyte alteration followed by IgE response. It is a Type I hypersensitivity reaction. The condition presents in three types which are :

  • Palpebral, affecting the upper tarsal conjunctiva, characterised by hypertrophied 'cobblestone' papillae
  • Bulbar-limbal, characterised by dusky red triangular congestion of the conjunctiva, gelatinous limbal papillae and Horner-Tranta's spots that are formed due to eosinophils and epithelial debris at the limbus
  • Mixed

Patients present with burning and itching sensation that worsen in warm, humid atmospheres, associated with ropy discharge (Maxwell Lyon sign), lacrimation and mild photophobia. Local spread leading to involvement of the cornea is termed vernal keratopathy. The condition is usually self-limiting but symptomatic treatment with anti-inflammatory therapy like topical steroids, mast cell stabilizers, antihistaminics and NSAID eye drops may be indicated, along with topical lubricating agents and mucolytics.

Other options:

Option A: Bacterial infection is responsible for acute or chronic bacterial conjunctivitis, usually characterized by painful red eye associated with a mucopurulent discharge.

Option B: Viral infection is responsible for various types of viral conjunctivitis which broadly present as follicular or hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. They are usually characterised by marked hyperemia with watery discharge, possibly associated with  systemic signs like fever and lymphadenopathy.

Option D: Granulomatous conjunctivitis is characterised by prominent nodule formation and unilateral involvement, and regional lymphadenitis, seen in conditions like tuberculosis, sarcoidosis and ophthalmia nodosa.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought by a lady police sub-inspector with an alleged history of sexual violence 2 days back. She was accompanied by her mother. The registered medical practitioner should do which of the following as the next step?

choices.text: Documentation of injuries and examination findings

questions.solution:
The registered medical practitioner should take a detailed history as the next step. 

The registered medical practitioner must take a detailed history and then take informed consent for examination. In case of refusal, an informed refusal is to be documented after explaining to them the consequences of choice. As part of the examination, they should collect specimens, preserve clothing, and document injuries and examination findings. Medical treatment and testing for pregnancy have to be done for all victims of sexual assault free of cost and police should be informed as per section 357-C of CrPc. 

The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012 considers all individuals (both male and female) below the age of 18 years as children and protects them from sexual abuse. It defines various forms of sexual offenses which include:

  • Sexual harassment: A person is said to commit sexual harassment upon a child when such person with sexual intent,
    • Carries out any act with sexual connotations
    • makes a child exhibit his/her body
    • shows any object to a child in any form/media for pornographic purposes.
  • Sexual assault
    • Any act with sexual intent that involves physical contact without penetration.
  • Aggravated sexual assault
    • Similar to sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term "aggravated".
  • Penetrative sexual assault
    • An act with sexual intent that involves physical penetration.
  • Aggravated penetrative sexual assault
    • Similar to penetrative sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term "aggravated".
  • Pornography

The term aggravated is used for those assaults done: 

  • by a person in a position of trust or authority such as police officer, security forces, relative, doctor.
  • in the course of communal violence.
  • on mentally & physically disabled.
  • gang sexual assault.
  • using deadly weapons.
  • causing grievous hurt

The Act prescribes stringent punishment graded as per the gravity of the offense, with a maximum term of rigorous imprisonment for life and fine. Section 21(1) of the POCSO Act, 2012 requires mandatory reporting of cases of child sexual abuse to law enforcement authorities and applies to everyone including parents, doctors, and school personnel. Failure to report a suspicion of child abuse is an offense under the Act.

questions.text: You suspect psoriatic erythroderma in a patient who presented with superficial scaling of the skin and redness. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for erythrodermic psoriasis is methotrexate. It is a folate antagonist that acts by the inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase. It inhibits lymphocyte proliferation and is thereby used in the management of generalized pustular psoriasis, psoriatic erythroderma and debilitating arthritis. 

Depending on the type of psoriasis, various therapeutic options are available:

  • Systemic agents - for moderate to severe psoriasis
    • Methotrexate
    • Acitretin
    • Cyclosporin
  • Phototherapy
  • Biologicals
    • TNF-alpha inhibitors: Infliximab, Etanercept, Adalimumab
    • IL 12 / 23 inhibitor: Ustekinumab
    • Selective IL-23 inhibitor: Tildrakizumab
    • IL-17 inhibitors: Secukinumab, Brodalumab
    • Phosphodiesterase-4 inhibitors: Apremilast

The only indication of systemic steroids is generalized pustular psoriasis in pregnancy (impetigo herpetiformis).

Erythrodermic psoriasis can be precipitated by the irritant effect of topical therapy, withdrawal of steroids, systemic illness, alcoholism and ultraviolet radiation. questions.text: A diabetic truck driver presents to you with cough and breathlessness.  A diagnosis of pneumonia was confirmed, and histopathological examination revealed dichotomous branching, as shown below. What is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The most likely causative agent based on the clinical features and image showing dichotomous branching at acute angles given is Aspergillus. 

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common pathogenic species. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients. This can be due to prolonged treatment with steroids or retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs. Voriconazole is the drug of choice.

Other manifestations include allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis where central bronchiectasis is usually seen. Aspergilloma and superficial infections like otomycosis or mycotic keratitis are the other presentations.

Histopathological examination of the tissue section shows characteristic dichotomous branching at an acute angle. The hyphae stain poorly with hematoxylin and eosin, so a periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) stain is used. 

Other methods for diagnosis include detection of galactomannan (Aspergillus cell-wall component) and culture isolation. Aspergillus fumigatus grows dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black. Yellow-green colonies are seen in the case of Aspergillus flavus. Microscopic examination of colonies stained with lactophenol cotton blue would show septate hyphae and conidiophores. 

Other options:

Options A and B - Rhizopus and Mucor are zygomycetes that are responsible for mucormycosis. Non-septate, broad hyphae are seen on tissue samples stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

The image below shows broad aseptate and irregularly-branched non-septate hyphae of Mucor.

Option C - Candida, the causative agent for candidiasis, appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Culture colonies are creamy-white and have a yeasty odor. Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species, form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

The image below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores. 

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A 28-year-old recently married woman committed suicide because of dowry torture by her husband's family. Under which of the following sections is this incident covered?
questions.solution:
This incident can be considered a dowry death. Dowry death is defined under section 80 BNS (304B IPC).

According to this, if the husband or his relative subjects the woman to cruelty or harassment in demand of dowry within 7 years of marriage; they shall be deemed to have caused her death. The punishment for such cases is imprisonment for not less than 10 years but may be extended to life imprisonment.

Option A: Section 106 BNS (304A IPC) defines the punishment for causing the death of a person by any rash or negligent act, not amounting to culpable homicide, the punishment is imprisonment for up to 2 years, and a fine.

Option C: Section 194 BNSS (174 CrPC) deals with the police inquest. It is done in suicide, homicide, killing by any animal or machinery or accident, and death under circumstances that raise suspicion of another person committing the offense.

Option D: Section 196 BNSS (176 CrPC) deals with magistrate inquest in which the cause of death is not under natural circumstances. Magistrate inquest may be conducted by the District Magistrate, Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Tahsildar, or any other executive magistrate empowered by the state government.

questions.solution:
The ocular finding depicted here is suggestive of band-shaped keratopathy and multiple sclerosis is not a cause of this condition. Multiple sclerosis causes optic neuritis.

Band-shaped keratopathy(BSK) is a corneal degenerative condition associated with the deposition of calcium salts in the deeper layers of corneal epithelium, Bowman's membrane and superficial part of the stroma.

lt typically presents as a band-shaped opacity in the interpalpebral zone with a clear interval between the ends of the band and the limbus. The condition begins at the periphery and gradually progresses towards the centre. Surface of this opaque band is stippled due to holes in the calcium plaques in the area of nerve canals of Bowman's membrane.

Treatment includes initially scraping of corneal epithelium under local anesthesia followed by chelation therapy with EDTA. 0.01 molar solution of EDTA solution is applied to the cornea with the help of a cotton swab for 10 minutes. Eye padding and bandage are then applied for 2-3 days to allow the epithelium to regenerate.

questions.text: Discrete probability distribution that expresses probability of a given number of events in a particular time frame is known as:
questions.solution:
Poissons distribution is the probability distribution that describes the chances of an event in a particular time frame.

For example, if you plot the number of patients visiting the OPD of your hospital for a week on a chart, you can conclude that on a particular day(say Monday) there are more number of patients. And if the pattern of patients is similar you can estimate the number of patients in OPD next week or so.

It is usually done for rare events and is depends on μ = λt (where μ defines the number of events in happening in time t)

Other options:
Gaussian distribution is another name for normal distribution.

Binomial distribution examples consist of those events which can only have two possible results given as yes or no / success or failure. It is usually done for finite number of events unlike Poissons distribution.

questions.text: An autopsy of a man who died due to a gunshot was done in which two bullets were found in his body. External examination revealed only one entrance wound. Which of the following mechanisms may help explain this?
questions.solution:
In certain cases, when a bullet fails to expel upon firing, a subsequent shot may cause both the original lodged bullet and the second bullet to enter the body through the same entry point. This phenomenon is referred to as a tandem or piggyback bullet.

The presence of an excess number of bullets compared to the observed entrance wounds can be attributed to factors such as weapon malfunctions, defective ammunition, prolonged non-usage of the loaded firearm, or exposure to extreme environmental conditions like high temperature or humidity. It is possible for the bullets to either separate within the body or before reaching the intended target.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man was brought to the casualty with a 3-day history of the findings shown. On examination, 50% of the body surface area was involved. Hemorrhagic cheilitis and crusting were also noted. What are the diagnosis and most probable underlying etiology?

choices.text: Stevens Johnson syndrome; Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection

questions.solution:
The given scenario of a serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes involving more than 30% of the body surface is suggestive of toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). Carbamazepine is commonly associated with SJS/TEN.

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS involves <10% of the body surface) and Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN involves >30% of the body surface) are primarily a drug‐induced phenomenon, with a culprit drug being demonstrated in approximately 85% of cases.

Common drugs that can cause SJS/TEN are:

  • Allopurinol
  • NSAIDs - oxicam group
  • Anti-epileptics - phenobarbital, phenytoin, carbamazepine, lamotrigine
  • Antibiotics - penicillins, cephalosporins, sulfamethoxazole, sulfasalazine, nevirapine

In 15% of the cases, where the drug cannot be identified, especially in children, it appear to be triggered by infections, most notably by Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

Note: FDA recommends genotyping before starting carbamazepine, as the HLA B1502 allele which is seen in increased frequencies among Asians is implicated in carbamazepine-induced SJS/TEN.

Other options :

Stevens Johnson syndrome is a drug-induced condition characterized by widespread epithelial keratinocyte necrosis of both skin and mucous membranes. It is due to cytotoxic T-lymphocytes. SJS with extensive involvement of skin (more than 30% of body surface area) is considered toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). The most common drugs involved in SJS/TEN are allopurinol, carbamazepine, lamotrigine, nevirapine, oxicam nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, phenobarbital, phenytoin, sulfamethoxazole, and sulfasalazine.

questions.text:
Match the following genetic diseases with their respective trinucleotide repeat sequences.

  1. Huntington’s disease               a. CGG
  2. Myotonic dystrophy                 b. GAA
  3. Friedreich ataxia                       c. CAG
  4. Fragile X syndrome                  d. CTG
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1 - c, 2 - d, 3 - b, 4 - a.

1. Huntington’s disease (HD) is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder. It is caused by CAG trinucleotide repeat (>40) expansion mutation in the huntingtin gene on chromosome 4p. The disease shows genetic anticipation and has an early-onset (second to the third decade) if inherited from the father. Cognitive impairment is an early feature. Pathologically, atrophy of caudate and putamen with ex vacuo ventriculomegaly is seen.  Decreased acetylcholine leads to dementia and decreased GABA and increased dopamine lead to chorea.

2. Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disease caused due to triplet repeat expansion of DNA in the DMPK gene. The polynucleotide sequence involved in the expansion is the CTG sequence. This leads to an abnormal expression of myotonin protein kinase. In the childhood form of DM,intellectual disability and behavioural problems are often the predominant features. Other key findings of classic DM include, Myotonia or delay in muscle relaxation, weakness and atrophy of facial and distal limb musculature, cardiac abnormalities including cardiomyopathy and conduction disturbances, frontal hair loss, cataracts, insulin resistance.

3.  Friedreich ataxia is the most common inherited ataxia. It is an autosomal recessive cause of spinocerebellar degeneration, caused by the expansion of GAA trinucleotides on chromosome 9. Most patients have pes cavus.

4. Fragile X syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability in males. It occurs due to CGG repeats in the untranslated regions(UTR) of the FMR1 gene.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient on ART with zidovudine, lamivudine, and indinavir develops pulmonary tuberculosis. Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs should be avoided in him?
questions.solution:
Rifampicin should be avoided as it is a potent inducer of CYP enzymes including CYPs 1A2, 3A4, 2C9, and 2C19, which in turn can induce the metabolism of indinavir and results in therapeutic failure of ART.

Rifabutin causes the least induction of cytochrome enzymes and is therefore preferred in HIV patients who are on protease inhibitors/NNRTIs.

Cytochrome enzyme-inducing potency of rifamycins is: rifampicin > rifapentine > rifabutin.

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby presented with hypertonia, irritability, and tonic spasms with light. These symptoms rapidly progressed resulting in the death of the baby. An autopsy was conducted and the histology of the brain parenchyma is shown below. Which of the following enzyme was deficient in him?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hypertonia, irritability and tonic spasms with light and the image showing characteristic globoid cells are suggestive of Krabbe disease. The enzyme deficient in Krabbe's disease is beta-galactosidase.

Krabbe's disease or globoid cell leukodystrophy is a neurodegenerative disorder with severe myelin loss and the presence of globoid bodies in white matter.

It is an autosomal recessive leukodystrophy due to the deficiency of galactocerebroside β-galactosidase. β-galactosidase helps in the catabolism of galactocerebroside to ceramide and galactose. As a result, an alternative catabolic pathway shunts galactocerebroside to galactosyl sphingosine. Elevated levels of these compounds are cytotoxic and cause the destruction of oligodendroglia.

The onset of symptoms is between 3 and 6 months of age, dominated by motor signs such as stiffness and weakness. Patients also have irritability and tonic spasms with light or noise stimulation. They often don't survive beyond the age of 2 years. The brain shows loss of myelin and oligodendrocytes with a similar process affecting the peripheral nerves.

The characteristic and diagnostic feature of Krabbe disease is the aggregation of engorged macrophages called globoid cells in the brain parenchyma and around blood vessels.

Other options:

Option B: A deficiency of enzyme alpha-galactosidase results in Fabry's disease. It is characterized by painful acroparaesthesia, hypohidrosis, abdominal cramping, diarrhea, small petechiae around the umbilicus, lenticular opacities, and corneal dystrophy.

Option C: A deficiency of enzyme beta-glucosidase results in Gaucher's disease. It is characterized by joint pain mostly affecting hips and knees, pancytopenia, convulsions, and hepatosplenomegaly. It shows crumbled tissue paper appearance on microscopy.

Option D: A deficiency in enzyme arylsulphatase A results in metachromatic leukodystrophy. It is characterized by progressive regression of milestones, ataxia dysarthria, hypotonia, spasticity hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and optic atrophy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady presents with generalised weakness and recurrent epistaxis. On examination, the spleen is not palpable. Blood investigations reveal Hb of 5 g/dL, platelet count of 15,000/μL, and WBC count of 3000/μL. What findings are expected to be seen in a bone marrow biopsy of this patient?

choices.text: Macrophages with characteristic crumbled tissue paper appearance.
Numerous needle-like azurophilic granules in the cytoplasm of the promyelocytes.
Erythroid hyperplasia with pathognomonic ring sideroblasts

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of generalised weakness, recurrent epistaxis, impalpable spleen and blood investigations showing pancytopenia, are suggestive of Aplastic anemia. Bone marrow biopsy reveals hypocellularity with fatty infiltration.

Aplastic anemia is a syndrome of chronic primary hematopoietic failure. This results in pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia). The patient will have

  • Decreased red blood cells leading to anemia
  • Decreased white blood cells leading to recurrent infections
  • Decreased platelets leading to petechiae and ecchymoses.

Many other leukemias and lymphomas may have a similar presentation. However, splenomegaly is characteristically absent in these patients. 

The bone marrow is markedly hypocellular. It is largely devoid of hematopoietic cells. Marrow aspirates yield a dry tap having only fat cells, fibrous stroma, lymphocytes, and plasma cells. Aplasia is best appreciated in marrow biopsies. 

The images given below show the normal and hypocellular bone marrow.

Treatment includes:

  • Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation - best method of management in young patients.
  • Antithymocyte globulin with cyclosporine - elderly patients and patients without HLA-matched donors.
  • Eltrombopag - a thrombopoietin analog used as an add-on therapy.

Other options:

Sideroblastic anemia are a group of disorders characterized by the presence of nucleated red cells (normoblasts) containing non-heme siderotic granules and stain prussian blue positive (sideroblasts). They can be also seen in myelodysplastic syndrome and lead poisoning.

questions.text: A young student with a history of heavy substance abuse developed psychotic symptoms. He became violent and attempted to kill his neighbours and strangers he saw on the street. Identify the substance he must have been abusing from the following.
questions.solution:
The substance that the student must be abusing is cannabis since he has features of run amok, in which the patient will go on a violent killing spree.

questions.text: You were posted as a medical officer in a Kala-azar endemic area. There was a rise in the number of insects shown in the given image below. Identify the insect:
questions.solution:
The image given is that of a sandfly (Phlebotomus), which is the vector for Kala-azar.

Sandflies are generally small insects, light or dark brown in color. They are smaller than mosquitoes. Their body and wings are densely clothed with hair. Their wings are up-right and lanceolate in shape and their legs are longer compared with the size of the body. They hop about and do not fly much. The species of sandfly responsible for transmitting the disease kala-azar is Phlebotomus argentipes. 

Kala-azar or visceral leishmaniasis is a protozoal infection mainly affecting the reticuloendothelial system. It is caused by various species of the genus Leishmania. It can present as visceral leishmaniasis, cutaneous leishmaniasis, ad mucosal leishmaniasis. Clinical features of the visceral form include moderate to high-grade fever with chills and rigors, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. 

The gold standard test for the diagnosis is the demonstration of amastigotes in the smears of tissue aspirates. Another commonly used test is the detection of antibodies to a recombinant antigen called rK39 by a rapid immunochromatographic test. In immunocompromised individuals, parasites can be isolated from the buffy coat. Amphotericin B is the first-line drug used in India. 

Other diseases transmitted by sandflies include sandfly fever and oriental sore.

For the reduction of sandflies, a  single application of DDT (dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) or lindane has been found effective. 

Other options:

Option A: Tsetse flies or glossinae are the blood-sucking flies that resemble the common houseflies. They are yellow or dark-brown in color. When folded, their wings overlap each other like the blade of a scissor. They have a non-retractile proboscis which is rigid and adapted for piercing the skin and sucking the blood. They are vectors for trypanosomiasis or sleeping sickness and are only found in regions in Africa.

 

Option C- Rat flea is the vector for plague and typhus. They are wingless, their head is conical in shape, and is directly attached to the thorax without a neck. The head has piercing mouth parts that are conspicuous and project downward for sucking blood. They have 3 pairs of legs attached to the thorax. 

Option D: Black flies are small robust flies. They are black short stout legs, large broad wings, and a short proboscis to suck blood. They are the vectors of onchocerciasis in Africa, Mexico, Central, and South America.

  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), oriental sore, sandfly fever and oraya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

questions.text: In the given left ventricular pressure-volume loop, which of the following corresponds to the 'c' wave of JVP?
questions.solution:
In the given left ventricular pressure-volume loop, the event that occurs between Points B and C is iso-volumetric contraction, which corresponds to the ‘c’ wave of JVP.

In iso-volumetric contraction, the ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.

The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction (systole) and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
  • c wave represents iso-volumetric contraction occurring in ventricular systole.
  • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening, during which both the right atrium and right ventricle are in diastole.

questions.text: The Myosin heavy chain (Mhc) gene in Drosophila encompasses a total of 30 exons which help transcribe many clusters of isoforms of length 2 to 5 exons. Supposing the canonical protein has a sequence of 262 amino acids and each isoform with 45-67 amino acids. What is the most probable phenomenon that can be noticed in this context?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon observed here is Alternative splicing as isoforms of proteins were transcribed from a single canonical protein. 

Alternative splicing is a form of gene regulation which can produce a variety of protein products from a single hnRNA (heterogeneous nuclear RNA/primary transcript). Suppose there are exons 1, 2,3 and 4. The splicing can be 1-2, 1-3, 1-4, 2-4, 2-3 etc. This leads to the formation of many variants of a protein from a single hnRNA. Alternative splicing has been identified in the case of at least 40 different genes. The calcitonin gene yields an RNA that synthesizes both calcitonin(in the thyroid) or calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP, in the brain). It is also responsible for the different types of Tropomyosin variants in muscle.

Other options :

Option A: Transposons, also known as jumping genes, are DNA sequences that have the ability to autonomously relocate themselves throughout the genome. The DNA component of the transposon is transcribed into RNA, which is subsequently reverse-transcribed back into DNA. This DNA is then inserted into a different location within the genome. Different isoforms forming from a single canonical protein cannot be explained by this phenomenon.

Option B: CpG methylation is an example of epigenetic modification which leads to reduced or inhibited transcription. Different isoforms forming from a single canonical protein cannot be explained by this phenomenon.

Option C: RNA interference is a process by which micro RNAs target the untranslated region in the 3' end after transcription to enable degradation. Different isoforms forming from a single canonical protein cannot be explained by this phenomenon.

questions.text: According to Casper's dictum, which of the following is correct with respect to the rate of decomposition of a body in air, water, and soil?
questions.solution:
Casper dictum states that a body decomposes in air twice as rapidly as in water, and eight times as rapidly as in earth. Therefore, the rate of decomposition is Air > Water > Soil. It is helpful in the estimation of time since death.  

Free access of air hastens putrefaction, partly because the air conveys organisms to the body. Putrefaction is rapid in a body buried in a damp, marshy or shallow grave without clothes or coffin, because the body is exposed to constant changes of temperature. Putrefaction is more rapid in warm, fresh water than in cold, salt water. It is more rapid in stagnant water than in running water.

Note: Forensic taphonomy is the study and interpretation of postmortem processes of human remains i.e. the history of a body following death.

The ratio of the time a body takes to decompose in air, water, and soil is 1:2:8. This means that the time taken by soil is greater than water and air. So, the correct order of time taken for decomposition is Soil > Water > Air. But, in this question, the rate of decomposition is asked, therefore, it is faster in air followed by water and soil i.e, Air > Water > Soil. (Note - Greater than is denoted by '>' and Less than is denoted by '<' i.e the opening is towards the higher side)

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is most likely to produce the following adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Cyclosporine is the drug that most likely produces the adverse effect shown in the image above, gum hyperplasia. 

Other drugs that cause gum hyperplasia are:

  • Phenytoin
  • Calcium channel blockers

Cyclosporine is an immunomodulator that binds with the cyclophilin protein and this complex inhibits the calcineurin activity. It decreases the T-cell activation and is useful in T-cell mediated transplant rejection. It is useful in autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, uveitis, Behcet's disease, atopic dermatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, nephrotic syndrome, etc. The major adverse effects are as follows:

  • Hirsutism
  • Gum hyperplasia
  • Nephrotoxicity
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Hypertension
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Altered mental status, seizures

Other options:

Option A- Carbamazepine is an antiepileptic agent used in the treatment of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, focal seizures, trigeminal and glossopharyngeal neuralgias, bipolar disorder, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. The main adverse events are hepatotoxicity, dilutional hyponatremia, hypersensitivity reactions, aplastic anemia, and agranulocytosis.

Option B- Tacrolimus is a macrolide antibiotic that binds to FKBP-12 protein (similar to cyclophilin) and inhibits calcineurin activity. It is indicated in the prophylaxis of solid-organ allograft rejection. Some of the adverse effects include nephrotoxicity, neurotoxicity, hypertension, and hyperglycemia.

Option D- Lamotrigine is an antiepileptic agent used in focal and generalized tonic-clonic seizures and Lennox Gestaut syndrome. The adverse effects include Stevens-Johnson syndrome, dizziness, ataxia, and double vision.

questions.text: A young man presented with hypertensive episodes, bloody stools and cutaneous nodules. He has a past history of hepatitis B infection. Vasculitis was suspected and a biopsy of the vessel was done. The histopathology of the tissue from the vessel is shown below. Identify the type of necrosis.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hypertensive episodes, bloody stools and cutaneous nodules with a history of hepatitis B infection is suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa and the above image depicts fibrinoid necrosis. It is seen in vasculitis like polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) in which the small and medium-sized blood vessels are affected as a result of immune complex deposition.

Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium and small-sized vessel vasculitis typically affecting the renal and visceral arteries, sparing pulmonary vessels. Patients present with variable symptoms including accelerated hypertension, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, myalgias and cutaneous nodules. It is often associated with chronic hepatitis B infection, which causes the HBsAg-HbsAb complexes to deposit in affected vessels. Clinical manifestations are a result of ischemia and infarction of organs and tissues that are affected.

The diagnosis is based on the histopathological findings seen on a biopsy of the involved organs. Diagnosis can also be made by the demonstration of aneurysms of small and medium-sized arteries in the renal, hepatic, and visceral vasculature. 

Fibrinoid necrosis occurs in blood vessels in which the antigen-antibody complexes get deposited in the blood vessel walls. These complexes elicit an immune reaction leading to cell injury and leakage of fibrin and plasma proteins around the blood vessel and giving a circumferential pinkish appearance of necrosis. 

It is treated with immunosuppressive agents and has a high risk of mortality if left untreated.

The image below shows fibrinoid necrosis with intraluminal thrombosis in an artery of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa. 

Necrosis refers to irreversible cell death caused by the denaturation of proteins and enzymatic digestion of the injured cells. 

Gangrenous necrosis commonly occurs in the lower limbs due to decreased blood supply. This type of necrosis is usually coagulative necrosis and is called dry gangrene.

When this becomes superimposed with bacterial infection the harmful enzymes from the bacteria and inflammatory cells result in liquefactive necrosis which is called wet gangrene.

Caseous necrosis (cheese like) refers to a friable yellow white area of necrosis as seen in this image

  • On microscopic examination, the necrotic focus appears as a collection of fragmented or lysed cells with an amorphous granular pink appearance surrounded by inflammatory cells called as granuloma and is classical of tuberculosis as shown below.

Fat necrosis refers to the localised destruction of fat by pancreatic enzymes. The commonest cause of this type of necrosis is acute pancreatitis. In acute pancreatitis, these enzymes are released within or around the pancreas breaking down the triglycerides into fatty acids. When calcium binds to fatty acid it results in fat saponification giving a chalky white appearance.

Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium and small-sized vessel vasculitis typically affecting the renal and visceral arteries. Patients present with variable symptoms including accelerated hypertension, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, myalgias and cutaneous nodules. It is often associated with chronic hepatitis B infection. Histology shows characteristic fibrinoid necrosis of the vessel wall with intraluminal thrombosis. This condition is treated with immunosuppressive agents and has a high risk of mortality.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with a penetrating injury to his left eye for which he was treated with corneoscleral suturing and discharged a week later. He returns 2 months later complaining of diminished vision, associated with redness, pain, and photophobia in the right eye. Direct ophthalmoscopy revealed discrete yellow-white nodules in the fundus. What part of the eye is most commonly affected?
questions.solution:
The clinical case is suggestive of sympathetic ophthalmitis, which is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis and hence the affected part is the uvea.

Dalen–Fuchs nodules are seen below the retinal pigment epithelium on ophtalmoscopy.

Sympathetic Ophthalmitis (SO) is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis occurring after penetrating trauma which usually begins 4–8 weeks after the injury to the eye (the exciting eye). It can also develop after surgeries, proton beam irradiation, Nd: YAG photocoagulation, and cryotherapy. It is an delayed hypersensitivity reaction mediated by T cells.

The exciting eye is often red and irritable, and the sympathizing eye may develop irritation, blurred vision, photophobia, and loss of accommodation.

Fundoscopy:

  • Multifocal choroidal infiltrates

questions.text:
Which of the following are true regarding vitamin D synthesis?
  1. Synthesis occurs sequentially in the skin, liver, kidney
  2. Cholecalciferol is produced in the skin
  3. 25 hydroxylase acts in the kidney
  4. 1-α-hydroxylase is present in the liver
questions.solution:
The true statements are statements 1 and 2.

The sequence of vitamin D synthesis is skin-liver-kidney. Cholecalciferol is produced in the skin. 

The sequence of vitamin D synthesis:

Step 1: In the skin: 7-Dehydrocholesterol (an intermediate in cholesterol synthesis that accumulates in the skin) undergoes a nonenzymic reaction on exposure to ultraviolet light, yielding cholecalciferol, which is absorbed into the bloodstream.

Step 2: In the liver:  Cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol (calcidiol). The enzyme responsible for this is 25 hydroxylase. This is released into the circulation bound to a vitamin D–binding globulin, which is the main storage form of the vitamin.

Step 3: In the kidney: 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to either 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol), the biologically active form by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase.

questions.text: Which of the following blood vessels is present in the hepatic fissure that corresponds to Cantlie’s line?
questions.solution:
The main portal fissure corresponds to the Cantlie’s line, and it contains the middle hepatic vein.

The Cantlie line is an imaginary line that extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver back to the midpoint of the inferior venacava (IVC). It anatomically divides the liver into the right and left halves. The clinical significance of this line is that it separates the left and right lobes of the liver. It is useful during a right or a left hepatectomy to determine the line of transection.

The liver has 3 major fissures which are:

  • The main portal fissure, corresponding to Cantlie's line divides the liver into right and left hemi-livers. It contains the middle hepatic vein.
  • The left portal fissure divides the left hemi-liver into medial (anterior) and lateral (posterior) segments. It contains the left hepatic vein. (Option B)
  • The right portal fissure divides the right hemi-liver into medial( anterior) and lateral (posterior) segments. It contains the right hepatic vein. (Option C)

Couinaud's classification is a functional classification which divides the liver into 4 sectors based on supply by portal venous branches (Option D). It is summarized in the pearl below.

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

questions.text: In a person with hearing impairment, brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA) was performed. Wave IV in the given image corresponds to the activity of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Wave IV of the given image corresponds to activity in the superior olivary nucleus.

Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is an objective and non-invasive method of hearing assessment that detects electrical activity from the inner ear to the inferior colliculus. 

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI – inferior colliculus
  • Wave VII - medial geniculate body

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text: A child presents with hoarseness of voice and the image of the subsequent laryngoscopy is shown below. The patient has no other symptoms. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
The image showing grape-like projections involving the anterior part of the vocal cords depicts a laryngeal papilloma. Laryngeal papillomas are benign tumours of the larynx caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV type 6 and 11) which is most likely acquired at birth from mothers who had vaginal HPV disease. 

They most commonly occur around 3 -5 years of age (juvenile papillomatosis) and involve the supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx. Seeding of the lesions can occur during invasive laryngeal procedures, such as intubation. They have a high recurrence rate and very low potential for malignancy. Adult-onset laryngeal papillomatosis is less common and usually seen in males aged 30-50 years. It also involves the anterior part of the vocal cords. 

Patients present with hoarseness, aphonia, dyspnea, or stridor. Laryngoscopy shows pinkish to white grape-like projections that can be sessile or pedunculated with a visible central vascular core. The diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. Treatment consists of micro-laryngoscopy, CO2 laser excision or topical Cidofovir application.

Other options:

Option B and C: Angioedema can be IgE-mediated (also with itching and urticaria) or inherited (deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor) and is characterized by recurrent episodes of edema that may involve the larynx and cause hoarseness. Laryngoscopy would show diffuse edema of the larynx. Below is a non-contrast CT showing angioedema of the larynx.

Option D: Reinke's oedema is a collection of fluid in the subepithelial space of Reinke. It generally occurs in patients with vocal abuse or smoking. The vocal cords will show diffuse, symmetrical swelling. The following image shows Reinke's edema.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows a laryngeal mirror which is identified by its straight shaft without any bends with a mirror at the end.

Indirect Laryngoscopy is done by the use of a laryngeal mirror.

The patient is seated straight opposite the examiner, with the head and chest leaning slightly towards him. He is asked to protrude his tongue which is wrapped in gauze for protection from any inadvertent injury. The tongue is held by the examiner between the thumb and middle finger.

The laryngeal mirror (size 4–6) is introduced into the mouth and held firmly against the uvula and soft palate. It should be warmed and tested on the back of the hand before introduction. Light is focused on the laryngeal mirror and the patient is asked to breathe quietly. Movements of both cords are seen and compared by asking the patient to take deep inspiration (abduction of cords), say “Aa” (adduction of cords), and “Eee” (for adduction and tension).

Structures seen on indirect laryngoscopy (in order) are:

  • The base of the tongue (posterior one-third of the tongue)
  • Vallecula
  • Median and lateral glossoepiglottic folds
  • Epiglottis
  • Pharyngoepiglottic folds
  • Aryepiglottic folds
  • Arytenoids
  • False vocal cords
  • True vocal cords

Other options:

Options A and C: St. Clair Thompson mirror is the other name for the Postnasal/ posterior rhinoscopy mirror. It has two bends in the shaft and is bayonet shaped.

Option D: A double hook retractor is used to retract soft tissues during surgery.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, and chemosis. Her thyroid profile showed she was euthyroid. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of thyroid ophthalmopathy.

Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of both bilateral and unilateral proptosis in an adult in the euthyroid state. The main features of TED include lid retraction, proptosis, periorbital edema, chemosis, and restrictive myopathy.

Other options-

Option A- Orbital pseudotumor presents with painful eye movements periorbital edema, erythema, proptosis, ptosis, diplopia

Option C- Orbital lymphoma usually presents in the 7th decade, most commonly observed as a painless palpable mass in the superolateral quadrant.

Option D- Orbital cellulitis is usually U/L condition with pain, proptosis, and chemosis

NOTE: Thyroid eye disease can also, though less commonly, occur in euthyroid patients.

questions.text: A child with delayed developmental milestones, lethargy and megaloblastic anemia which does not respond to treatment with iron, folic acid ,vitamin B12 or pyridoxine, with elevated level of orotic acid in urine.  Which among the following will alleviate the symptoms?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical findings is suggestive of orotic aciduria.

Uridine is a pyrimidine nucleoside that can be useful in treating orotic aciduria as it bypasses the missing activity in the pathway and can be converted to other pyrimidines.

Orotic aciduria is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a defect in uridine monophosphate (UMP) synthase. This enzyme contains two activities, orotate phosphoribosyltransferase and orotidine decarboxylase. The lack of pyrimidines impairs nucleic acid synthesis needed for hematopoiesis, explaining the megaloblastic anemia in this infant. Orotic acid accumulates and spills into the urine, resulting in orotic acid crystals and orotic acid urinary obstruction. The presence of orotic acid in urine might suggest that the defect could be ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency, but the lack of hyperammonemia rules out a defect in the urea cycle.

Adenine, Guanine and hypoxanthine are purines.

questions.text: Which of the following prevents the release of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction?
questions.solution:
Botulinum toxin prevents the release of acetylcholine in the brain and neuromuscular junction.

Botulinum toxin cleaves synaptobrevin which is a VAMP (vesicle-associated membrane protein). These are presynaptic membrane proteins needed for  the fusion of synaptic vesicles containing acetylcholine to the terminal membrane. Therefore they block the release of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction and cause flaccid paralysis. Symptoms can include ptosis, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphonia, and dysphagia.

 

Other options:

Option A- Hemicholinium blocks choline uptake with consequent depletion of acetylcholine in the terminals of cholinergic fibres.

Option B- Curare competes with Acetylcholine for receptors on the motor endplate.

Option D- Neostigmine inhibits acetylcholinesterase at the muscarinic and nicotinic sites.

questions.text: An epidemiologist gives a lecture on pandemics. He gives influenza pandemics as an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Influenza pandemics are an example of a cyclical trend.

A cyclical trend is a type of periodic fluctuation. It occurs in cycles that are spread over short periods of time. This can be days, weeks, months, or even years.  Examples of the cyclic trend include influenza and rubella. Some non-infectious conditions can also display cyclical trends. An example of this is road traffic accidents occurring more frequently on the weekends. Knowledge of the cyclical pattern of diseases can be used to defend communities against the same.

Other options:

Option A: Seasonal trend is another type of period fluctuation which refers to seasonal variation of diseases. Examples of diseases that follow this trend include measles, malaria, and upper respiratory tract infections. It can be related to environmental conditions such as temperature and humidity. Some non-infectious conditions which follow this trend are sunstroke, hay fever, and snakebite. Some epidemiologists consider this a form of cyclic trend.

Option B: Secular or long-term trend signifies the changes seen in the occurrence of a disease over a long period of time. It implies a consistent change in a particular direction such as a progressive increase or decrease. Examples of conditions that follow this pattern are coronary heart disease and lung cancer which have shown a consistent upward trend. A decline in the occurrence of diseases such as tuberculosis and diphtheria has been noted in developed countries. 

Option C: Point-source epidemic is a type of common-source epidemic. In this type of epidemic, there are no secondary waves and the epidemic curve rises and falls rapidly. There is a clustering of cases within a narrow interval of time. All the cases develop within one incubation period of the specific disease.

questions.text: Which of the following tests can be done to confirm the diagnosis of rabies?
questions.solution:
Viral culture is used to confirm the diagnosis of rabies.

Multiple tests in succession/simultaneously are the best. Usually Direct Fluorescent Antibody test followed by virus isolation/culture is useful.

Virus isolation through culture: The best specimens are brain and saliva. CSF, corneal smears, and centrifuged urine can also be used.

Option A: Serological tests like indirect immunofluorescence are insensitive.

Option B: Negri bodies can only be demonstrated in the brain (pyramidal cells of Ammon’s horn, and the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum are the most common site).

Option D: Real-time-PCR Amplification Detection of rabies virus RNA is highly sensitive and specific. This technique can detect viruses in fresh saliva samples, skin, CSF, and brain tissues. However, it is not a confirmatory test.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman who was a nonsmoker came to the medicine department with complaints of cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss. Bronchoscopy suggested a lung carcinoma and biopsy showed a lepidic growth pattern. Which of the following is the most likely immunohistochemical marker for this lesion?

choices.text: Thyroid transcription factor-1 and napsin A

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a non-smoker woman presenting with cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, and lung biopsy showing a lepidic pattern (butterfly on the fence) is suggestive of adenocarcinoma of the lung. Immunohistochemical markers in adenocarcinoma lung are thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) and napsin A.

Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of lung cancer seen in women and nonsmokers. Adenocarcinomas are usually located in the periphery as compared to other lung tumors and are relatively smaller in size. Atypical adenomatous hyperplasia is a precursor lesion of adenocarcinoma. Microscopic examination shows a lepidic pattern of growth at the periphery of the tumor. The tumor cells appear to crawl along the normal-appearing alveolar septa, as shown in the image below.

 

Other options:

Option A: Calretinin and cytokeratin 5/6 positive staining are seen in malignant mesothelioma. It is difficult to differentiate epithelioid mesothelioma grossly and histologically from adenocarcinoma. Immunohistochemical stains help to make this differentiation. The image below shows the epithelioid type of mesothelioma showing cuboidal, columnar, or flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma. Inset shows strong positivity for calretinin immunohistochemical stain.

 

Option C: p40 and p63 are markers of squamous cell carcinoma lung. It is the most common cancer found in smokers. Histologically it is characterized by the presence of keratinization and markedly eosinophilic cytoplasm as shown below.


Option D: Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers of small cell carcinoma lung. Due to the encrustation by DNA from the necrotic cancer cells, vascular walls in the necrotic area take up basophilic staining as shown below. This is called the Azzopardi effect.

questions.text:
A primary health care center evaluated school-going children to assess their nutritional status. The data collected is given below. What is the median weight in this case?

10kg, 15kg, 12kg, 19kg, 21kg, 17kg, 25kg
questions.solution:
The median weight, in this case, is 17kg.

The median is a measure of a central tendency of data and is obtained by arranging the data in an ascending or descending order of magnitude and then recording the value of the middle observation. For example, the data above needs to be rearranged in ascending order as:

10 kg, 12 kg, 15 kg, 17 kg, 19 kg, 21 kg, 25 kg

The middle value is 17 kg and hence the median in this case.

If there is an even number of values, then the median is estimated by taking the average of the two middle values. 

Central tendency provides a numerical summary that gives an idea about the central, average, or typical score in a distribution of scores for a variable. Other measures of central tendency are:

  • Mean - obtained by dividing the sum of individual observations by the number of observations.
  • Mode - defined as the most frequently occurring value in a distribution of data.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (b) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (c) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (a) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient presented with painless, foul-smelling ear discharge from the right ear. The angle of the mouth has deviated to the left side. On otoscopic examination, multiple perforations were seen in the pars tensa of the tympanic membrane. Identify the causative organism for this condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the diagnosis as tubercular otitis media and Mycobacterium tuberculosis is the causative agent.

The above clinical scenario of painless, foul-smelling discharge, facial palsy with multiple perforations in the pars tensa of the tympanic membrane are suggestive of tubercular otitis media.

Tubercular otitis media is usually secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis where the infection spreads to the middle ear through the eustachian tube or is blood-borne from the tubercular focus. It is more commonly seen in children and young adults.

It presents as a painless condition, with foul-smelling discharge from the ear. Multiple perforations in pars tensa of the tympanic membrane and pale granulations in the middle ear cleft are seen. Severe hearing loss, mostly conductive type is seen in tubercular otitis media. If the labyrinth is involved then, sensorineural hearing loss can occur. Facial palsy is a common complication in the tubercular otitis media.

Diagnosis is based on the culture of the ear discharge for tubercle bacilli, histopathological examinations of granulations, and chest radiograph.

Treatment includes systemic antitubercular therapy, local treatment with an aural toilet, and mastoid surgery in cases of complications.

Other options:

Options B, C, and D- Streptococcus pneumonia, Hemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis are the most common causative organisms for acute suppurative otitis media(ASOM). Acute suppurative otitis media is an acute inflammation of the middle ear caused by pyogenic organisms. It is differentiated into 4 stages:

  • Stage of tubal occlusion- The symptoms are deafness and earache. Otoscopic signs include retracted tympanic membrane with a horizontal position of the handle of malleus, prominent lateral process of malleus, loss of light reflex.
  • Stage of presuppuration- The symptoms are marked earache, deafness, tinnitus, and a high grade of fever. Otoscopic signs include congested pars tensa of the tympanic membrane and cart-wheel appearance (leash of blood vessels appear along with the handle of malleus and at the periphery of the tympanic membrane). 
  • Stage of suppuration- The symptoms are excruciating earache, deafness, and fever. Otoscopic signs include red and bulging tympanic membrane with loss of the landmarks 
  • Stage of resolution- Earache is relieved with the evacuation of the pus. A small perforation is seen on the anteroinferior quadrant of pars tensa. Hyperemia of tympanic membrane subsides.

Below is an image showing the cart-wheel appearance of the tympanic membrane.

ASOM by antibiotics, decongestant nasal drops, analgesics, aural toilet, and myringotomy to relieve pus.

questions.text: Which of the following components is a part of the Physical Quality of Life Index?
questions.solution:
Literacy rate is one of the components of the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI). All other options are components of the human development index (HDI).

Physical Quality of Life Index measures three indicators:

  • Infant mortality rate
  • Life expectancy at age one
  • Literacy rate

For each indicator, the performance of a country is rated from 0 to 100, where 0 is the worst performance and 100 is the best performance. PQLI is calculated by taking the average of the three indicators, with equal weightage for each of the indicators. 

The index is used for international and national comparison. It measures the results of social, economic, and political policies. The PQLI does not take into account the per capita income of the country. Therefore, the Middle East countries that are rich, in fact, have a lower PQLI compared to Sri Lanka or the state of Kerala in India.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of watering eyes and inability to keep eyes opened in a bright room. On ocular examination, the following finding is noted. The finding is a defect in which of the following layers of the cornea?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with photophobia and excessive watering and image showing Haab striae is suggestive of congenital glaucoma. Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in the descemet membrane.

Primary congenital glaucoma refers to abnormally high intraocular pressure (IOP) which occurs as a result of a developmental anomaly of the angle of the anterior chamber. It is not associated with any other ocular or systemic anomaly. It can be classified as follows:

  • True congenital glaucoma (40%) in which intraocular pressure (IOP) is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma (55%), which manifests prior to age 3.
  • Juvenile glaucoma, the least common, in which IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Diagnosis:

  • Corneal haze is due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP.
  • Buphthalmos is a large eye as a result of stretching due to elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane.
  • Corneal scarring

Below image shows hazy cornea.

Evaluation under general anesthesia is generally required; IV ketamine lowers IOP to levels lower than those achieved with other agents.

Treatment:

  • Management is essentially surgical.
  • Goniotomy
  • Trabeculotomy
  • Other procedures when angle surgery fails include trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures.

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic male patient was found to have open-angle glaucoma and was started on a drug that increases uveoscleral flow. What is the drug given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Latanoprost is a prostaglandin drug, which acts by increasing the uveoscleral outflow and thereby lowers the intraocular pressure. 

Mechanism of action: Latanoprost is a prodrug and gets activated during its passage through the cornea. It acts by stimulating the prostanoid receptors on the ciliary muscles. This leads to the release of matrix metalloproteinases, which increases the uveoscleral outflow.

Topical prostaglandins like latanoprost, travoprost, bimatoprost, and tafluprost are now used as first-line agents to lower IOP. The major mechanism of action is by enhancing the uveoscleral outflow though they also increase trabecular outflow.

The most common ocular side effects are conjunctival hyperemia, eyelash thickening, iris hyperpigmentation, and loss of periorbital fat. These drugs are administered once every day at bedtime and are used with caution in inflamed eyes.

The systemic side effects are uncommon and include occasional headaches, malaise, myalgia, skin rash, and mild upper respiratory infections. Latanoprost is preferred as the first-line due to fewer ocular side effects.

Other options:

Option A: Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It reduces IOP by decreasing aqueous production. 

Option C: Mannitol is an osmotic agent, which lowers IOP by creating an osmotic gradient so that water is pulled from the vitreous into the blood vessels. It is used as a short-term treatment to reduce IOP in acute angle-closure glaucoma or prior to intraocular surgery.

Option D: Pilocarpine is a miotic that acts as a cholinergic agonist. In angle-closure glaucoma, cholinergic agents open the angle by contraction of the sphincter pupillae, pulling the iris away from the trabecula.

questions.text:
During your visit to the CHC, you observe the ANM taking one frozen vaccine vial as a control and another vial of the same vaccine. She shakes both vials and attempts to compare the sedimentation rate of the solutes in them. For which of the following vaccines would you not conduct this test?

ANM- Auxiliary Nurse Midwife
questions.solution:
The shake test detects the freeze damage to vaccines. It is used for all freeze-sensitive vaccines - all the 'T-series' vaccines. The shake test is not used for the Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR) vaccine.

The freeze damage to vaccines is detected by the shake test.

  • A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.
  • Both are shaken after thawing and the rate of sedimentation is compared.
  • If the rate of sedimentation in the test vial is slower than the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.
  • Some of the most widely used vaccines are freeze-sensitive. Examples: Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis, Liquid Haemophilus influenza type b (Hib), Hepatitis B.

Related Pearl: Measles vaccine

Measles vaccine: 

  • Type: Live attenuenated, lyophilized (freeze dried), vaccine (Tissue culture vaccine- chick embryo or Human diploid cell line).

  • Strains used: 1. Edmonston Zagreb strain (most common). 

                            2. Schwartz strain.

                            3. Moraten strain.

  • Dose: 0.5ml.

  • Route: Subcutaneous.

  • Site: Right arm (usually).

  • Age of administration in National immunization schedule (India): 9 months (can be lowered to 6-9 months in epidemics and malnutrition) and 16-24 months.

  • Diluent for reconstitution: Distilled water or sterile water. (To be used within 4 hours after reconstitutuion).

  • Measles (and MMR) vaccine can lead to Toxic shock syndrome.

  • Measles vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

  • Cold chain temperature for storage: +2 to +8 degree Celcius.

  • Protective efficacy: >90% with one dose; >99% with two doses.

  • Duration of protection: Life long.

  • IP of vaccine induced measles: 7 days.

  • Ideal gap between two successive doses: 6 months.
