  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.

questions.text: A 48-year-old chronic alcoholic was administered an infusion of multivitamins. He developed skin flushing and pruritus. An ophthalmic check-up done later revealed macular oedema with cysts. A toxicity with which of the following vitamins is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Macular cysts and oedema may develop in patients due to the infusion of supraphysiological doses of vitamin B3 (niacin toxicity).

The toxic effects of niacin include:

  • Flushing associated with skin dryness, pruritus, paresthesia, and headache. These effects may be seen with even a low dose of 30mg/day. Premedication with aspirin alleviates these symptoms (as these symptoms are mediated by prostaglandins)
  • Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
  • Hepatic toxicity, which presents as jaundice with elevated AST and ALT levels.
  • Fulminant hepatitis requiring liver transplantation.
  • Glucose intolerance
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Macular oedema and macular cysts.

questions.text: A newborn infant is found to have a congenital urethral abnormality in which the urethral meatus opens on the ventral side of the penis. It is resulting in difficulty in directing the urine stream due to the ventral curvature of the penis. Which of the following is the cause of this malformation?

choices.text: Failure of the fusion of urethral folds

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes hypospadias. It occurs due to the incomplete fusion of the urethral folds.

Development of external genitalia in males

It is under the influence of androgens secreted by the fetal testes. The genital tubercle elongates to form phallus. During this elongation, the phallus pulls the urethral folds forward so that they form the lateral walls of the urethral groove. This groove extends along the ventral aspect of the elongated phallus, but not up to the glans. The urethral folds which form the lateral wall of the urethral groove fuse to form the penile urethra. The most distal part of urethra is formed by the penetration of the ectodermal cells from the tip of the glans. These form a short epithelial cord that forms the external urethral meatus.

Incomplete fusion of the urethral folds leads to hypospadiasis. 

Other options:

Option A- Splitting of genital tubercles leads to bifid or double penis.

Option C- Improper development of urorectal septum or cloaca leads to absent perineal and anal openings in association with ambiguous genitalia and urogenital and colonic malformations.

Option D- Improper developmental paramesonephric duct leads to uterine anomalies like uterus didelphys, uterus arcuatus, uterus bicornis, etc.

The majority of the patients have an X-linked inheritance. Clinical features include hematuria, proteinuria, and sensorineural hearing loss. It is seen as a characteristic basket weaving appearance of lamina densa as shown below.

No specific therapy is recommended to treat Alport syndrome. Proteinuria can be treated with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin 2 receptor blockers.

questions.text:
During a medical camp at a school, you record the visual acuity of a child to be 6/30 for distant vision. According to ICD 11, which category of visual impairment does the child fall under?

ICD 11- International Classification of Disease 11
questions.solution:
A child having a visual acuity of 6/30 for distant vision falls under moderate distant vision impairment according to ICD 11 classification.

Classification of visual impairment according to the International Classification of Disease 11 (2018):

  • Distance vision impairment:
    • Mild - Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/12
    • Moderate - Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/18
    • Severe - Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/60
    • Blindness - Presenting visual acuity worse than 3/60
  • Near vision impairment:
    • Presenting near vision acuity worse than N6 or N8 at 40cm with existing correction.

questions.text: Permanent alteration of the fingerprint pattern occurs in all of the following conditions, except ________.
questions.solution:
Permanent alteration of the fingerprint pattern does not occur in acromegaly.

Fingerprints are impressions of patterns formed by the papillary or epidermal ridges of the fingertips. The arrangement and distribution of the ridges not only remain unchanged throughout life but is unique for each individual. The study of this ridge pattern in the skin is called dermatoglyphics or dactylography and helps in the identification of the individual.

However, permanent impairment of the fingerprint pattern occurs in leprosy, electrical injury, and subsequent radiation exposure.

In acromegaly, there is a change in the distance between the ridges but no permanent impairment in the fingerprint pattern. A similar change is observed in infantile paralysis and rickets. Ridge alteration can also occur in eczema, acanthosis nigricans, scleroderma, and dry or atrophic skin. Additionally, there is moderate epidermal ridge atrophy and loss of pattern in celiac disease.

questions.text: A medical officer is conducting a case-control study and employs matching to select controls similar to the cases. Which of the following types of bias is likely to be reduced as a result?
questions.solution:
Matching controls to be similar to the cases is likely to reduce confounding bias or bias due to confounding factors.

A confounding factor is one that is related to both exposure and disease and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. Irrespective of being associated with the exposure under study, the confounding factor might itself serve as a risk factor for the disease. Hence, the elimination of these confounding factors is essential before carrying out a case-control study. 

Matching, which is usually done in analytical studies (such as a case-control study), is the process where the participants in two groups (cases and controls in this case) are matched based on factors that are known to influence the outcome of disease (such as age, gender, race, etc.) to stop the potential confounders from distorting the results.

Other strategies to eliminate confounding factors include randomization, stratified randomization, and restriction.

Other options:
Option A - Recall bias in case-control studies occurs because history recollection is better in the case group as they have a stronger exposure than the control group. This bias can be reduced by decreasing the recall period as much as possible.

Option C - Selection bias is a type of sampling bias that occurs because of the nonrandom allocation of subjects such that the study population is not representative of the target population. The best way to reduce this is by randomization to create groups with similar distributions of known and unknown variables. 

Option D - Interviewer bias is a type of bias that occurs because the interviewer is aware of the case group and the hypothesis being tested, which can influence interviews and analysis. This can be reduced by blinding to reduce their influence on interviews and interpretation of outcomes.

Type A personality is associated with competitiveness, restlessness, hostility, and a sense of urgency or impatience. These individuals are more prone to CHD than the Type B personality which is calmer, and more philosophical.

questions.text: A body of a 30-year-old man is retrieved from the local river and subjected to autopsy. His family accuses his friend of murdering him by pushing him into the river after making him unconscious by hitting his head with a wooden stick. Which autopsy finding will favor the family's accusation?
questions.solution:
The finding of edema aquosum in the autopsy will favor the family's accusation.

Edema aquosum occurs when the victim is alive but unconscious at the time of the drowning. This is mere flooding of the lungs with the water without the formation of froth as respiratory efforts are absent.

Autopsy findings in drowning include, froth in the air passages, waterlogging of the lung, emphysema aquosum, paltauf’s spots, hemorrhage into the middle ears and into the temporal bone.

Other options :

Option B: Hydrostatic lung, is seen in postmortem drowning. When a dead body is thrown into the water, water passes into the lungs due to hydrostatic pressure. 

Option C: Emphysema aquosum - This is seen in cases when the victim is alive and conscious. Overinflation of the lungs in drowning is known as emphysema aquosum. It is one of the most valuable positive signs of drowning. The edema fluid in the bronchi blocks the passive collapse that normally occurs at death. Hence, the lungs are held in the inspiratory position. The impression of the ribs on this overinflated lung leaves visible and palpable grooves on the lateral surface. 

Option D: Diatom test- Diatoms are microscopic algae. Their presence in the organs, particularly in the bone marrow, is suggestive of antemortem drowning. In postmortem drowning, diatoms do not spread to distant organs because of absence of circulation and are limited to the lungs.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the pediatrics department with poor sucking and difficulty in taking feed. He also had severe foul smelling greasy loose stools. A peripheral smear showed acanthocytosis. A biopsy specimen of the small intestine is shown below. Identify the underlying condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of an infant presenting with failure to thrive, steatorrhea, acanthocytosis in the peripheral smear, and a histopathological image showing lipid-laden vacuolated epithelium is suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia.

Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare autosomal recessive disease. It is caused due to the mutation in microsomal triglyceride transfer protein which leads to the inability to assemble triglyceride-rich lipoproteins. Thus lipids get accumulate intracellularly. It is predominantly seen in children during their first year of life. They present with failure to thrive and steatorrhea.

Deep tendon reflexes are absent due to peripheral neuropathy and peripheral smear shows acanthocytosis due to lipid membrane defects, which is secondary to marked vitamin E deficiency.

Histopathology shows normal intestinal mucosa except lipid-laden vacuolated epithelium due to triglyceride accumulation. Accumulated lipids disappear after infants stop taking feed.

Low fat, high caloric, vitamin-enriched diet, and vitamin E in large doses should be given. Inadequate supply of vitamin E results in neurological degeneration and the development of retinitis pigmentosa.

Diarrhea is defined as an increase in stool mass, frequency, or fluidity, typically greater than 200 gm per day. It can be classified into 4 types:

  • Secretory diarrhea is an isotonic stool and persists during fasting.
  • Osmotic diarrhea is due to the osmotic force exerted by unabsorbed luminal solutes. The diarrheal fluid is greater than 50 mOsm. Diarrhea decreases on fasting.
  • Malabsorptive diarrhea is due to failure of nutrient absorption. It is associated with steatorrhea and it gets relived on fasting.
  • Exudative diarrhea is due to inflammatory diseases which has pus and blood on them, it continues during fasting.

Other options:

Option A- Lactase deficiency is due to the absence of lactase in the villous epithelial cells. Lactose remains in the intestinal lumen and exerts an osmotic force causing osmotic diarrhea. Since the defect is biochemical, histology appears normal.

Option C- Celiac disease is an immune-mediated disorder triggered by gluten-containing foods. Histology shows villous atrophy intraepithelial lymphocytosis and crypt hyperplasia. Plasma cells, mast cells, and eosinophils are seen in lamina propria.

Histopathology image of celiac disease is shown below:

Option D- Whipple's disease is a malabsorptive syndrome. Histology shows foamy macrophages in the small intestinal propria. The macrophages are laden with gram-positive, periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) positive, diastase resistant granules that have partially digested Tropheryma whipplei within the lysosome.

questions.text: A patient with a history of renal calculi has been on a low calcium diet for several weeks. On further investigation, which of the following is the most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most likely finding in this patient would be elevated levels of parathormone (PTH).

A diet low in calcium eventually leads to hypocalcemia, which stimulates PTH release. Hence, this patient will have high PTH levels.

  • PTH acts on the kidneys to increase the absorption of calcium.
  • PTH also increases the level of the enzyme 1-α hydroxylase which leads to more production of the active form of Vitamin D- 1,25 dihydrocholecalciferol.

In the presence of hypocalcemia, serum calcitonin levels decrease and the active form of vitamin D increases.

questions.text: A woman who underwent cholecystectomy now presents with abdominal pain one month later. An erect abdominal X-ray was taken, and the image is shown below. Which of the following options best describes the condition?
questions.solution:
The x-ray shows a pair of surgical scissors left behind in the abdomen after surgery. The offense comes under res ipsa loquitur. It is obvious evidence of the negligent act committed.

"Res ipsa loquitur" means "the thing or fact speaks for itself." The negligent act is so obvious that the patient need not prove the negligence. He has to merely state what according to him was the negligent act.

This doctrine applies to both civil and criminal negligence. All of the following conditions should be fulfilled for this doctrine:

  • In the absence of negligence, there would not have been any injury usually
  • The doctor had complete control over the injury-producing instrument or treatment.
  • The patient was not a part of contributory negligence.

Other options:

Option A: Novus actus interveniens - A person is responsible not only for his actions but also for the logical consequences of those actions. This principle applies to cases of assault and accidental injury.

Option C: Res judicata - If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same in another legal proceeding, based on the same set of facts. Multiple appeals cannot be made. 

Option D: The principle of respondeat superior is used to explain vicarious liability, which explains that the employer is responsible for his employees’ negligence if such an act occurs in the course of the employment and within its scope.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male patient presented with a history of fever, sore throat, and enlarged lymph nodes. He was prescribed ampicillin after which he developed a maculopapular rash. Which of the following is the standard diagnostic test for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young adult with fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and development of a maculopapular rash after administration of ampicillin are suggestive of Glandular fever/ Infectious mononucleosis.  It is caused by the Epstein Barr virus (EBV). The standard diagnostic test for this condition is the Paul Bunnell test, which is a heterophile antibody reaction test.

Heterophile antibodies have the ability to agglutinate RBCs of different animal species. Paul Bunnell test uses sheep erythrocytes for agglutination.

In Infectious Mononucleosis, heterophile antibodies can usually be demonstrated by the end of the first week of illness, but are occasionally delayed until the third or fourth week and may persist for months.

An agglutination titer of 100 or above is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis.

Other serological tests such as immunofluorescence and ELISA are employed to detect antibodies against EBV.

  • The lgM antibody to VCA (virus capsid antigen) appears soon after primary infection and disappears in 1-2 weeks. It indicates primary infection.
  • The IgG anti-VCA antibody persists throughout life and indicates past or recent infection.
  • The new appearance of antibodies to the EB nuclear antigen (EBNA) is a marker for primary infection.

Other options:

Option A: Cold agglutination test is used to detect primary atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma.

Option B: Weil-felix test is used for Rickettsial infection.

Option D: Microscopic agglutination test is used for diagnosing Leptospirosis.

questions.text: A young male patient presented with a high fever, muscle aches, and easy fatigability. He gives a history of diarrhea and abdominal pain about 20 days ago. His blood investigations revealed eosinophilia. His muscle biopsy findings are given in the image below. What is the most likely organism responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the muscle biopsy findings showing encysted spiral larvae are characteristic of Trichinella spiralis.

Trichinella spiralis is known as the pork worm since the infection is acquired by consuming raw or undercooked pork. The initial infection presents as diarrhea and abdominal pain. In the later phase of the infection, the larvae move from the intestines into the circulation and migrate into muscles where they are encysted. This causes symptoms like fever, myalgia, etc.

The larvae more commonly infect active muscles like the diaphragm, tongue, intercostals, extraocular muscles, etc. These larvae are calcified in about 5-6 months. Eosinophilia caused by parasitic infection also comes down after 6 months.

It can be treated using albendazole along with steroids to control inflammation.

questions.text: Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome is caused by excessive activation of which of the following pathways?
questions.solution:
Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is caused by excessive activation of the alternative complement pathway.

Atypical or familial HUS is an inherited cause of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia associated with thrombocytopenia and renal failure. It is caused by defects in complement factor H, membrane cofactor protein, or factor I. All these factors serve as complement regulators. Deficiency of these causes impaired control and excessive activation of the alternative complement pathway.

Typical HUS occurs in children following a gastrointestinal infection caused by Shiga toxin-producing strains like E. coli O157:H7 or Shigella dysenteriae. It is characterized by widespread injury to small vessel endothelium, leading to thrombotic microangiopathy.

  • C5a is also a chemotactic agent.
  • Opsonization and phagocytosis: C3b and its cleavage product iC3b (inactive C3b) act as opsonins and promote phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.
  • Cell lysis

This role of complement is important mainly for the killing of microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria species, and deficiency of the terminal components of complement predisposes to Neisseria infections.

questions.text: Name the condition for which the incision A is made in the image below
questions.solution:
The above incision is a circumferential incision used to relieve acute suppurative otitis media. This incision is made in the posteroinferior tympanic membrane to avoid injury to the incudo-stapedial joint. 

A radial incision is incision B made to allow suction of a serous otitis media. 

Myringotomy refers to the incision made on the tympanic membrane with the purpose to drain suppurative or nonsuppurative effusion of the middle ear or to provide aeration in case of a malfunctioning eustachian tube.

Indications of myringotomy:

  • Acute suppurative otitis media and its complications
  • Recurrent acute otitis media
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the Eustachian tube)
  • Atelectatic ear (treated along with grommet insertion)

Contraindication of myringotomy: It is contraindicated in suspected cases of intratympanic glomus tumor, as it can cause profuse bleeding in such patients.

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought with the complaints of protrusion of the right eye with no h/o fever. CT Scan showed a well-defined mass in the orbit with an irregular border and adjacent bony destruction. Biopsy showed small, round cells which were positive for Desmin in Immunohistochemistry. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with complaints of protrusion of eye with well-defined mass in the orbit and adjacent bony destruction on CT scan and biopsy showing small, round cells positive for Desmin favors rhabdomyosarcoma. 

Cavernous hemangioma(option B) and orbital cellulitis(option C) usually are associated with fever, hence ruled out. Retinoblastoma(option A) is associated with Flexner–Wintersteiner rosettes on microscopy, therefore its not correct. 

Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of childhood usually in the head and neck region, most common primary orbital malignancy in children. They are malignant tumors arising from voluntary muscle and produce a rapidly increasing proptosis. It extends in all directions. Diagnosis is done using biopsy in which cross-striations in the tumor cells are pathognomonic. Myoglobulin is a specific marker but it can also be positive for desmin.

Subtypes include embryonal(majority), alveolar, botryoid and pleomorphic.

Treatment includes combination of chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

  • Two injections of vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and actinomycin D are given at weekly intervals before radiotherapy.
  • Radiotherapy is given during which vincristine and cyclophosphamide are administered weekly.
  • After radiotherapy, a combination of vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and doxorubicin is given for a year or longer in those patients in whom metastases were detected.

Other options:

Option A: Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14.  White pupillary reflex or leukocoria is the most common presenting feature, followed by a squint which is usually convergent. Histopathology of the tumor shows small round cells with large nuclei. Microscopic features includes Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes(highly specific of retinoblastoma), Homer-Wright rosettes, pseudorosettes, and fleurettes formation. Areas of necrosis and calcification can also be seen. 

Option B: Cavernous hemangioma is the most common primary benign orbital tumor in adults. They are composed of large, dilated vascular channels; are more infiltrative; frequently involve deep structures; and do not spontaneously regress. On histologic examination, the mass is sharply delineated but unencapsulated with large, cavernous blood-filled vascular spaces, separated by connective tissue stroma.

Option C: Orbital cellulitis is the most common cause of unilateral proptosis in children. It refers to the acute infection of the contents of the orbit behind the orbital septum. Features include pain, lid edema, erythema, chemosis, and axial proptosis. Increased pain with movement of eyes and ophthalmoplegia(decreased ocular motility) is a classic symptom. With posterior exenteration cavernous sinus thrombosis, subdural empyema, and intracranial abscess develop.

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding suicidal inhibition.

choices.text: The inhibitor can bind with any site resulting in suicidal inhibition
The binding of the enzyme to the substrate analogue is irreversible
They are enzyme specific and used in rational drug design
The inhibitor forms a product with the enzyme and the product inhibits it

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding suicidal inhibition is the inhibitor can bind with any site resulting in suicidal inhibition.

In suicidal inhibition, the inhibitor can only bind with the active site of an enzyme and is unreactive outside the confines of the enzyme's active site. 

The enzyme inhibition helps to modify the rate of reactions it catalyzes and this inhibition can either be reversible or irreversible. Reversible inhibitors bind to enzymes through non-covalent bonds. Irreversible inhibitors usually bind to an enzyme through covalent bonds and do so strongly so that it can no longer dissociate.

Suicide inhibitors are a category of irreversible inhibitors also called mechanism-based inhibitors. They are specialized substrate analogs that contain a chemical group that reacts with the catalytic machinery of the target enzyme. In these types of inhibitors, the substrate analog irreversibly ties up with the binding site of an enzyme, deceiving the enzyme by concealing its functional group resulting in the formation of a highly reactive molecule, which brings about self-inactivation of the enzyme.

Suicide inhibitors bind to the enzyme by means of covalent bonds; they are enzyme-specific and unreactive outside the confines of the enzyme’s active site.

An example of this would be the binding of clavulanic acid to the active site of beta-lactamases in bacteria. Clavulanic acid mimics the structure of a beta-lactam antibiotic and forms a covalent adduct with the β-lactamase active site. This leads to a rearrangement that creates a much more reactive derivative, which is subsequently attacked in its active site to irreversibly acylate the enzyme and inactivate it. Thus, amoxicillin and clavulanic acid are combined to overcome bacterial resistance to amoxicillin alone.

The development of clavulanic acid to target beta-lactamase-producing bacteria is also an example of the rational design of drugs. Rational design of drugs refers to the ability to predict the appropriate molecular structure of a drug on the basis of information about its biological receptor.

questions.text: A man was found to be lying dead on the ground. His friend saw a snake passing in the area and took a picture of it and showed it to the doctor (image below). What is the most probable cause of death of this man?
questions.solution:
The snake in the given image with single white bands on the body is a Common krait which is neurotoxic and the most probable cause of death in this patient is respiratory failure. 

Bites of elapidae (Cobras, Kraits, Mambas, Coral Snakes) present with a local bite reaction which is generally mild with minimal swelling, blistering or superficial necrosis. However, their neurotoxic effects are prominent and early symptoms usually include vomiting, hypersalivation, headache, the heaviness of the eyelids, blurred vision, tingling sensation around the mouth, hyperacusis, dizziness, vertigo, and ‘gooseflesh’. 

Ptosis is the earliest neuroparalytic manifestation followed by ophthalmoplegia. This is followed by paralysis of the facial muscles, palate, jaws, tongue, vocal cords, and neck muscles. Muscles of deglutition become progressively flaccidly paralyzed. A respiratory arrest may occur due to obstruction of the upper airway by the paralysed tongue or inhaled vomitus, or due to paralysis of intercostal muscles and diaphragm.
 
Other options :
 
Cause of death in Viper bite(hemotoxic) is Shock and haemorrhage, consumption coagulopathy.
 
Cause of death in Sea snakes(myotoxic) is cardiac arrest due to hyperkalemia caused by renal failure or respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with complete obstruction of his left nostril and a nodule on the dorsum of the nose obscuring his vision as shown in the image. He gives a typical history of foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crust formation even before this nodule developed. Histology of the biopsied specimen is given as an image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of rhinoscleroma.

It can be diagnosed as rhinoscleroma, as the patient had a history of purulent foul-smelling nasal discharge with crusting before the development of nodule, which corresponds to the atrophic stage of rhinoscleroma 

Adding to this, the given histology shows large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli, which are Mikulicz cells

Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

It has 3 stages

Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.

Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative Granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of woody/hebra nose.

Cicatricial stage – Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. The deformity is called tapir nose.

Treatment: Streptomycin (1g/day) and tetracycline (2g/day) are given together for a period of 4 to 6 weeks. Steroids can be combined with this to reduce fibrosis. Surgical treatment is necessary to restore the airway and correction of the nasal deformity.

Other options:

Option B: Rhinophyma or potato tumour is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland and presents as swelling over tip of the nose.

Option C: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a swelling in the skull. The radiological finding was suggestive of lytic lesions. A bone biopsy was performed and the ultrastructure of the biopsied tissue is shown below. Identify the structure seen.
questions.solution:
The scenario with a young child presenting with a skull swelling with lytic lesions on radiography and the given image of the biopsy reveals Birbeck granules/bodies. This is suggestive of the diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).

LCH is a clonal proliferation of pathological Langerhans cells. Men are more affected than women. Patients present with pain and swelling over the affected areas. Commonly affected sites are the skull, pelvis, femur, and mandible. Radiographs show a lytic lesion with periosteal new bone formation. In the skull, lesions appear as a hole within a hole, and in the vertebra, vertebra plana (flattening of the vertebral body) can be seen. 

Histopathologically, it is characterized by the presence of Langerhans cells. The tumour cells contain abundant cytoplasm with folded or grooved nuclei. Ultrastructurally, they contain tennis-racket-shaped intracytoplasmic inclusions called Birbeck granules. The tumour cells specifically express HLA-DR, S-100, and CD1a and langerin (CD207) markers.

The image below shows a histopathological image of Langerhans cells with folded nuclei (coffee-bean nuclei).

Other options: 

Options B and C:  Asbestos bodies shown below are a hallmark finding of asbestosis. They appear as golden brown, fusiform, or beaded rods. These are formed when the asbestos fibers are phagocytosed by the macrophages and are coated by iron-containing proteinaceous material derived from phagocyte ferritin. Similar iron-protein complexes coat other inorganic particulates other than asbestos which are termed ferruginous bodies.

Option D: Schaumann bodies are seen in non-caseating granuloma of sarcoidosis. They are laminated concretions composed of calcium and protein.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of repeated pain over the medial canthus and chronic use of nasal decongestants presents to the OPD with high-grade fever, chills, headache, and bilateral proptosis. On eliciting further history, it was confirmed that proptosis began in the right eye, and a few days later, the left eye was also affected. Fundoscopy reveals papilloedema. On examination, damage to the abducens nerve was noted. Which of the following ocular movements will be impaired?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, with recurrent episodes of headache and pain over the medial canthus and repeated use of nasal decongestants, suggests that the patient was suffering from sinusitis, which has most likely resulted in cavernous sinus thrombosis, and the injury of the abducens nerve will affect the lateral ocular movement as it supplies the lateral rectus muscle of the eye.

Cavernous sinus syndrome (CSS) is a rare condition characterized by ophthalmoplegia, proptosis, ocular and conjunctival congestion, trigeminal sensory loss, and Horner’s syndrome. These signs and symptoms result from the involvement of the cranial nerves passing through the cavernous sinus. The cavernous sinus syndrome affects III, IV, V, and VI cranial nerves.

In cavernous sinus thrombosis, proptosis is initially unilateral but soon becomes bilateral due to the spread of infection to the contralateral sinus through the intercavernous communication. Also, cavernous sinus thrombosis presents with high-grade fever with chills, rigor, and headache.
On the other hand, orbital cellulitis and panophthalmitis are unilateral conditions

The cavernous sinuses are two large venous plexuses that lie on either side of the body of the sphenoid bone, extending from the superior orbital fissure to the apex of the petrous temporal bone.

Structures related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinuses are the oculomotor nerve, trochlear nerve and the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. Within the cavernous sinus are the abducens nerve and the cavernous part of the internal carotid artery.

Image showing cavernous sinus and the structures related to it.

Orbital apex syndrome is a condition similar to cavernous sinus syndrome with retro-orbital pain and involvement of 2,3,4,5 and 6 cranial nerves. The differentiating feature is the optic nerve involvement leading to early visual loss and afferent pupillary defect.

questions.text: Which of the following is the sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community?
questions.solution:
The infant mortality rate (IMR) is a sensitive indicator of the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of health care in a community.

Infant mortality rate (IMR) = Number of deaths in the first year of life/Total number of live births x 1000.

It is one of the universally accepted healthcare indicators for the whole population and the socioeconomic conditions under which they live.

Other options:

Option B:  While the maternal mortality rate is an important indicator of maternal healthcare services, it is not as sensitive as the infant mortality rate in reflecting the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare in a community.

Option C: Immunization coverage is an essential factor in preventing diseases and promoting public health. However, it is a narrower indicator than the infant mortality rate, focusing primarily on preventive healthcare services for children. Full immunization coverage is defined as the proportion of infants 9-11 months old who have received the 3 doses of DPT vaccine, BCG vaccine, 3 doses of OPV, and one dose of measles vaccine against the estimated number of infants during a specific year.

Option D: Disability-adjusted life years are a useful measure of the overall burden of disease in a population, but they are less sensitive in assessing the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of healthcare services in a community compared to the infant mortality rate.

questions.text: The following image shows the reabsorption and secretion of various ions. In which part of the nephron is this seen?

choices.text: Descending limb of the loop of Henle
Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
The given image shows a portion of the late distal convoluted tubule. This can be identified by the following features represented in the diagram:

  • Presence of two distinct types of cells, the principal cells, and intercalated cells.
  • The principal cells are identified by the reabsorption of sodium and secretion of potassium into the lumen.
  • The intercalated cells are identified by the absorption of potassium with the secretion of hydrogen ions into the lumen.
  • Presence of water absorption in the presence of anti-diuretic hormone (ADH)

Note that these features are also seen in the collecting duct. The late distal tubule and collecting duct are similar anatomically and functionally.

In the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), sodium, water, and chloride are mainly reabsorbed here along with glucose, amino acids, and other solutes. The total solute concentration or osmolarity remains the same all along the proximal tubule due to the high permeability to water.

The thin descending limb of the loop of Henle is permeable to water, urea, and sodium. The tubular fluid becomes hypertonic in this segment. The thick ascending limb reabsorbs Na+, K+, and Cl- by a Na+-K+-2Cl- co-transporter. Some of the K+ that is reabsorbed leaks back into the lumen, creating a potential difference with more positivity in the lumen. This lumen positivity is responsible for the absorption of divalent ions like Ca+2 and Mg+2. The thick ascending limb is virtually impermeable to water. Since some of the solutes are reabsorbed and water is not reabsorbed, it dilutes the tubular fluid.

Early distal convoluted tubule (DCT) reabsorbs Na+ and Cl- by the Na+-Cl- co-transporter. This segment is also impermeable to water. Because of the relative solute reabsorption, there is dilution of the tubular fluid.

The late distal tubule and collecting duct have two kinds of cells as mentioned above. Principal cells reabsorb Na+ and secrete K+ into the lumen. The Na+ reabsorption is through epithelial Na+ channels (ENaC). The expression of ENaC is mediated by aldosterone and thus increases whenever there is activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. The absorption of Na+ is balanced by the secretion of K+ into the lumen.

The water permeability of the principal cells is controlled by ADH. When ADH levels are high, aquaporin 2 channels are inserted in the luminal membrane of the principal cells, leading to water reabsorption.

Intercalated cells reabsorb K+ and secrete H+ by an H+-K+ counter-transporter. They also have an H+ pump which is responsible for acid secretion.

questions.text: Identify the type of joint shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
The type of joint shown in the given image is syndesmosis. 

The radius and ulna are united with each other by three joints:

  • Proximal (superior) radioulnar joint
  • Middle radioulnar joint
  • Distal (inferior) radioulnar joint

Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm.

The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint (syndesmosis). The radius and ulna, in the middle, are connected by two syndesmoses namely:

  • The oblique cord - extends from the lateral side of the ulnar tuberosity to the radius, distal to the radial tuberosity.
  • Interosseous membrane - a broad, thin collagenous structure, which runs perpendicular to the oblique cord. It extends distomedially between the interosseous borders of the radius and ulna.

Based on the structure, joints are classified into three types:

  • Fibrous joints
    • Sutures
    • Syndesmosis
    • Gomphosis
  • Cartilaginous joints
    • Primary cartilaginous joints or synchondrosis
    • Secondary cartilaginous joints or symphysis
  • Synovial joints
    • Ball-and-socket or spheroidal joints
    • Sellar or saddle joints
    • Condylar or bicondylar joints
    • Ellipsoid joints
    • Hinge joints

questions.text: A 38-year-old man came to the orthopedic outpatient clinic with a high stepping gait and is found to have a fracture at the neck of the fibula on an X-ray. This is associated with a loss of sensation in which of the following area/areas of the foot?
questions.solution:
A fracture at the neck of the fibula and a high stepping gait (foot drop) suggests injury to the common fibular nerve. This is associated with loss of sensation over the dorsum of the foot (marked 4) and the first interdigital space (marked 1). 

The nerves supplying the marked areas are shown below.

The common fibular nerve is derived from the dorsal branches of the 4th and 5th lumbar and 1st and 2nd sacral ventral rami. It runs obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa to the fibular head. It lies between the biceps femoris and the lateral head of the gastrocnemius. It then curves laterally around the neck of the fibula and gets divided into superficial and deep fibular nerves. 

The first interdigital space is supplied by the deep fibular nerve while the dorsum of the foot (except lateral and medial borders) is supplied by the superficial fibular nerve.

  Superficial fibular nerve Deep fibular nerve

  • Peroneus longus

  • Extensor digitorum longus

  • Tibialis anterior
  • Peroneus tertius
Sensory innervation
  • Lateral aspect of the lower leg
  • Dorsum of the toes except for the lateral side of the 5th toe and the first interdigital webspace

 
  • The first interdigital space
 

 

Injury to the common peroneal nerve at the level of the neck of the fibula causes foot drop. Ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and eversion of the foot are lost, while the inversion and plantar flexion are usually preserved. Sensory innervation to the dorsum of the foot, including the first web space, is lost. The ankle reflex is usually preserved.

Other options:

Area 2 represents the lateral aspect of the foot which is supplied by the sural nerve.

Area 3 represents the medial aspect of the foot which is supplied by the saphenous nerve.

questions.text: During periods of prolonged fasting, one of the following tissues preferentially uses fatty acids as energy-providing substrates. It is because this tissue has the highest concentration of lipoprotein lipase. Identify this tissue.
questions.solution:
The highest concentration of lipoprotein lipase is found in the cardiac muscle. This leads to preferential usage of fatty acids to provide most of the energy needed for cardiac function.

Lipoprotein lipase is an extracellular enzyme which is present in the capillary walls of most tissues. It is chiefly synthesised by the adipose tissue, cardiac and skeletal muscles.

According to the nutritional and hormonal level the expression of tissue specific iso-enzyme takes place :

  • Fed state (elevated insulin ) : LPL is predominant in adipose tissue but decreased in muscle tissue
  • Fasting (decreased insulin ) LPL is more in muscle tissue rather than adipose tissue 

A deficiency of lipoprotein lipase or apo C-II leads to type 1 hyperlipoproteinemia or familial chylomicronemia which leads to increased risk of acute pancreatitis.

Other options :

Lipoprotein lipase is not active in the adult liver. This prevents the degradation of chylomicrons and VLDL in the liver. Instead, the liver has hepatic lipase that is involved in the degradation of chylomicron remnants and HDL.

Lipoprotein lipase is found in the heart, lung, adipose tissue, renal medulla, aorta, diaphragm, lactating mammary gland and spleen.

questions.text: A father reports to a pediatrician that his daughter has episodes of lethargy, irritability, and vomiting right after she drinks any fruit juice. Urinalysis after such an episode was positive for Benedict's test. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is likely in this girl?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with symptoms occurring after ingesting fruit juices (containing fructose) points to the diagnosis of hereditary fructose intolerance, and aldolase B enzyme deficiency seen here.

Fructose-1,6- bisphosphate aldolase/ aldolase B is present in the liver, kidney, and intestine. It catalyzes the hydrolysis of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate into triose phosphate and glyceraldehyde phosphate. It also hydrolyzes fructose-1-phosphate.
 
Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive condition, caused by pathogenic variations in the ALDOB gene which causes aldolase deficiency.
 
Patients are asymptomatic until fructose or sucrose is ingested (usually from fruit, fruit juice, sweetened cereal, or table sugar). It usually presents during infancy when sugar-containing feeds are introduced, but some patients (who are less sensitive) can present at older ages as well. Clinical features include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. Acute ingestion causes symptomatic hypoglycemia. Chronic intake results in failure to thrive, hepatic disease, kidney failure, and death.
 
Reducing substances are seen in the urine during an episode (Benedict's test positive) as fructose is a reducing sugar. Reduced levels of aldolase B activity in the liver and demonstration of two pathogenic variants in ALDOB on molecular genetic testing give a definitive diagnosis.
 
Treatment involves complete cessation of all sources of sucrose, fructose, and sorbitol from the diet.
 
The image summarizes the metabolic pathways involved in the metabolism of fructose.

Other options:

Option B: Fructokinase converts fructose to fructose-1-phosphate, the deficiency of which can give rise to essential fructosuria. Essential fructosuria is a benign, asymptomatic defect of intermediary metabolism characterized by the intermittent appearance of fructose in the urine.

Option C: Glucose-6-phosphatase is located in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and catalyzes the hydrolysis of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose and phosphate. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to Von Gierke disease characterised by hypoglycemia, growth retardation, and hepatomegaly.

Option D: Hexokinases catalyse the first step in glucose metabolism, i.e, phosphorylation of intracellular glucose.

questions.text: 1 yr old boy presents with biphasic stridor, barking cough and difficulty in breathing and fever. Image given below depicts his Xray findings. All of the following are true about this condition except_____________

choices.text: Most common in age group of 6 months to 3 years
Most common organism responsible is Parainfluenza virus

questions.solution:
The clinical picture of biphasic stridor, barking cough and difficulty in breathing, and fever in the child along with the steeple sign on x ray, is suggestive of croup or laryngotracheobronchitis. Biphasic stridor suggests subglottic involvement (not supraglottis).

Croup or laryngotracheobronchitis is an inflammatory condition of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi caused by the parainfluenza virus (Option D). It is characterized by the subglottic swelling of loose areolar tissue leading to respiratory obstruction and stridor. It commonly affects children between 6 months and 3 years of age, more often male children. (Option A and B)

Laryngotracheobronchitis is characterized by a barking cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor. Agitation and crying aggravate the symptoms and signs. A hoarse voice, coryza, normal to moderately inflamed pharynx, and a slightly increased respiratory rate can be revealed in the physical examination. The upper airway obstruction may progress and the child can present with an increased respiratory rate, nasal flaring; suprasternal, infrasternal, and intercostal retractions; and continuous stridor. On X-ray a Steeple/Church top/pencil top sign (obstruction in subglottis) is seen.

Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

questions.text: Identify the pelvic diaphragm in the picture given below.
questions.solution:
The structure marked "1" is the levator ani muscle which is part of the pelvic diaphragm.

Other structures marked in the above image are

2: External anal sphincter

3: Internal anal sphincter

4: Pudendal canal

Pelvic diaphragm 

The muscular part of the pelvic floor is the pelvic diaphragm. It is attached to the pelvic wall on either side between the greater and lesser sciatic foramen. Levator ani and coccygeus muscles form the pelvic diaphragm and delineate the lower limit of the true pelvis. 

Levator ani is formed by pubococcygeus, iliococcygeus, and puborectalis. The muscles blend together posterior to the vagina in women and around the anus in both sexes. Posterior to the anal aperture, the form the anococcygeal body attaches to the coccyx. Urogenital hiatus is present anteriorly separating the muscles. This allows the urethra and vagina to pass through. Levator ani reinforces the external anal sphincter. In women, it functions as the vaginal sphincter. 

The coccygeus muscles, one on each side are triangular in shape and form the posterior part of the pelvic diaphragm. The apices are attached to the tips of ischial spines. The bases are attached to the coccyx and sacrum.

questions.text: A young man with a history of motion sickness presents to your OPD with upcoming plans for a road trip. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?

choices.text: Ondansetran one night before and also before trip

questions.solution:
Scopolamine (Hyoscine) transdermal patch is the most appropriate treatment for motion sickness before a trip.

It should be applied behind the ear about 5-6 hours before the journey, and gives protection for around 72 hours against motion sickness, after which the patch can be replaced if necessary.

Scopolamine is also used for narcoanalysis as it causes sedation and amnesia.

Dimenhydrinate is a first-generation antihistamine that can also be used in motion sickness. Although dimenhydrinate may have equal efficacy it is not preferred because of its sedating properties.

questions.text: You are a researcher studying the mechanism of action of statins which inhibit the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase by acting as a structural analog to its natural substrate. The Lineweaver Burk Plot for the interaction is given below. Which of the following is true about this type of inhibition?
questions.solution:
The given example of statin inhibiting cholesterol synthesis by acting on HMG-CoA reductase and the graph is a type of competitive inhibition. True about competitive inhibition is that the Km of the reaction increases.

Important parameters in a reaction include:

  • The affinity of the enzyme for its substrate is given by the Michaelis constant or Km. A low Km reflects a high affinity of the enzyme for substrate and vice versa. The value of Km is given by the substrate concentration at which the reaction velocity is equal to one-half Vmax. It does not change with changes in enzyme concentration. 
  • The rate of the reaction is directly proportional to the enzyme concentration.

Competitive inhibition is when the inhibitor binds reversibly to the substrate-binding site and competes with the substrate for the active enzyme binding site.

This effect of competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration by which maximum velocity can still be achieved. Therefore, Vmax is unaltered in this type of inhibition. However, the concentration of the substrate required to achieve half of the maximum velocity is increased. Therefore, Km is increased in this condition.

Noncompetitive inhibition is by binding of inhibitors to enzymes in locations remote from the active site. Increasing the concentration of the substrate does not overcome non-competitive inhibition. Thus, noncompetitive inhibitors decrease the Vmax of the reaction. They do not interfere with the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. Thus, the enzyme shows the same Km in the presence or absence of noncompetitive inhibitors.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about the adductor canal except?

choices.text: Roof is bound by the fascia and sartorius

questions.solution:
All of the following statements are true about the adductor canal/Hunter's canal/subsartorial canal, except that femoral nerve is a content.

The adductor canal is an intermuscular space situated in the distal two-thirds of the medial aspect of the thigh. This canal extends from the apex of the femoral triangle to the distal attachment of the adductor magnus. On cross-section, it is triangular in shape. 

The adductor canal is bound anterolateral by the vastus medialis (option D), posteromedially by the adductor longus, and distal to the adductor longus by the adductor magnus. Its anteromedial boundary or the roof is by a strong and dense fascia (option A) that extends from the medial surface of the vastus medialis to the medial edge of the adductors longus and magnus. This fascia is below the sartorius muscle and hence is termed the subsartorial fascia. 

The contents of the adductor canal are:

  • Femoral artery (option C)
  • Femoral vein
  • Saphenous nerve
  • Nerve to vastus medialis
  • Descending genicular and muscular branches of the femoral artery

The femoral vessels travel through the adductor canal and enter the popliteal fossa via the adductor hiatus which is an opening in the adductor magnus tendon adjacent to the femoral shaft.

questions.text: Which of the following is not required for calculation of creatinine clearance?

choices.text: Volume of serum passing through kidney in 24 hours

questions.solution:
The volume of plasma passing through the kidney in 24 hours is not used in the calculation of creatinine clearance.

The parameters used to calculate creatinine clearance (CCr) are:

  • Urine creatinine
  • Serum creatinine
  • 24hr urine output

The formula used to calculate creatinine clearance (CCr) is:

        UCr × V ⁄ PCr  where,

UCr - Urine creatinine(mg/dl)

PCr - Serum creatinine(mg/dl)

V - Urine volume(ml/24 hrs)

Creatinine is a metabolite of muscle metabolism and is cleared from the body mostly by glomerular filtration. Therefore, the clearance of creatinine is used to assess GFR.

Urine collection for the measurement of creatinine clearance may be subject to practical constraints. Therefore, approximate changes in GFR can be obtained by measuring the serum creatinine concentration, which is inversely proportional to GFR.
